decision.title: Parliament Moves to Equalize EU Workers' Rights with Montenegrin Citizens to Close Chapter 2
decision.summary: Parliamentary majority MPs submitted amendments to the Law on Social and Child Protection that would guarantee EU, EEA, and Swiss citizens the same social protection rights as Montenegrin nationals. The move is a key step toward closing EU accession Chapter 2 (Freedom of Movement of Workers), aligning Montenegro with EU Directive 2014/54/EU. Mobile workers would be protected from nationality-based discrimination in accessing social and child protection benefits. The amendments are set to take effect immediately upon publication in the Official Gazette. Reported by Investitor.me.
decision.title_mne: Parlament se kreće ka izjednačavanju prava radnika EU sa pravima crnogorskih građana radi zatvaranja Poglavlja 2
decision.summary_mne: Poslanici parlamentarne većine podnijeli su amandmane na Zakon o socijalnoj i dječijoj zaštiti kojima bi se građanima EU, EEP-a i Švajcarske garantovala ista prava na socijalnu zaštitu kao i crnogorskim državljanima. Ovaj korak predstavlja ključni napredak ka zatvaranju Poglavlja 2 u procesu pristupanja EU (Sloboda kretanja radnika), čime se Crna Gora usklađuje sa Direktivom EU 2014/54/EU. Mobilni radnici bili bi zaštićeni od diskriminacije po osnovu državljanstva u ostvarivanju prava na socijalnu i dječiju zaštitu. Amandmani stupaju na snagu odmah po objavljivanju u Službenom listu. Izvještava Investitor.me.

assessments.summary: This decision concerns EU accession Chapter 2 (Freedom of Movement of Workers) and social protection law, which falls outside the direct mandate of the Ministry of Environment. While the Ministry welcomes any progress on EU accession as it builds institutional momentum toward closing all chapters including Chapter 27 (Environment and Climate Change), this specific legislative amendment has no direct environmental implications. The decision neither advances nor hinders environmental protection, coastal zone management, waste management, or climate policy.
assessments.executive_summary: This social protection amendment targeting Chapter 2 closure has no direct environmental impact. The Ministry of Environment views it as neutral but notes that comparable legislative urgency should be directed toward the significantly more demanding Chapter 27 benchmarks, where Montenegro faces substantial compliance gaps.
assessments.reasoning:
The amendments to the Law on Social and Child Protection are designed to align Montenegro with EU Directive 2014/54/EU and close Chapter 2 on Freedom of Movement of Workers. This is a social policy and labor rights matter with no substantive connection to environmental protection, biodiversity, waste management, spatial planning, or climate change adaptation.

From an indirect perspective, the Ministry notes two relevant observations. First, progress on any EU accession chapter is broadly positive because it demonstrates legislative capacity and political will to harmonize with the EU acquis. Chapter 27 remains one of the most complex and resource-intensive chapters, requiring transposition of over 200 pieces of EU environmental legislation. Any demonstration that Parliament can move swiftly on accession-related amendments is encouraging.

Second, the speed and apparent ease with which these Chapter 2 amendments are being advanced stands in contrast to the pace of progress on Chapter 27. Montenegro opened Chapter 27 in 2018, yet significant gaps remain in areas such as full transposition of the Industrial Emissions Directive, completion of Natura 2000 site designation, establishment of a functioning waste management system aligned with the circular economy package, and enforcement of Environmental Impact Assessment procedures. The Ministry would welcome equivalent parliamentary urgency on pending environmental legislation.

There is a minor secondary consideration: equalizing rights for EU and EEA mobile workers could marginally increase the resident population in coastal and tourist areas, which could have downstream effects on waste generation, water demand, and spatial planning pressure. However, this effect is negligible in the context of this specific legislative change and does not warrant a non-neutral verdict.
key_concerns: No direct environmental relevance, meaning this decision does not advance Chapter 27 compliance
The contrast between swift action on Chapter 2 and slow progress on Chapter 27 environmental benchmarks raises questions about legislative prioritization
Pending environmental legislation such as updates to the Law on Environmental Impact Assessment and the Law on Waste Management continues to await parliamentary attention
Montenegro's 2024 interim benchmarks for Chapter 27 remain partially unmet, particularly regarding air quality, waste infrastructure, and nature protection
recommendations: Apply the same legislative urgency demonstrated for Chapter 2 to pending Chapter 27 legislation, including amendments to the Law on Environmental Protection and the Law on Nature Protection
Use the momentum from closing Chapter 2 to advance parliamentary debate on transposing the EU Circular Economy Package into Montenegrin law
Ensure that any future amendments related to freedom of movement account for spatial planning implications in high-migration coastal municipalities such as Budva, Kotor, and Tivat
Prioritize parliamentary scheduling for the long-delayed update to the National Climate Change Strategy and accompanying legislative framework

counter_proposal.title: Parallel Fast-Track for Priority Chapter 27 Legislation
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Environment proposes that Parliament adopt a parallel fast-track procedure for critical Chapter 27 legislation, mirroring the expedited approach used for Chapter 2 amendments. Specifically, a package of three to four priority environmental laws should be submitted for accelerated parliamentary consideration within the same legislative session.
key_changes: Bundle priority Chapter 27 amendments (EIA law update, waste management framework revision, and nature protection law alignment with EU Habitats and Birds Directives) for expedited parliamentary procedure
Establish a dedicated parliamentary working group for Chapter 27 legislative alignment with a clear timeline and quarterly progress reporting
Require that each accession chapter closure be accompanied by a progress assessment on Chapter 27 to maintain political visibility for environmental compliance
expected_benefits: Accelerated progress toward Chapter 27 interim and closing benchmarks
Demonstration to the European Commission that Montenegro treats environmental acquis with the same seriousness as other chapters
Reduced risk of environmental compliance becoming the primary bottleneck for overall EU accession
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible. The legislative drafting capacity exists within the Ministry and supporting agencies, but political will and parliamentary scheduling remain the primary constraints. The Chapter 2 precedent demonstrates that fast-track procedures are available when political motivation exists.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Paralelna ubrzana procedura za prioritetno zakonodavstvo iz Poglavlja 27
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo životne sredine predlaže da Parlament usvoji paralelnu ubrzanu proceduru za ključno zakonodavstvo iz Poglavlja 27, po uzoru na ubrzani pristup koji je primijenjen za izmjene u Poglavlju 2. Konkretno, paket od tri do četiri prioritetna zakona iz oblasti životne sredine trebalo bi uputiti na ubrzano parlamentarno razmatranje u okviru iste zakonodavne sjednice.
key_changes_mne: Objedinjavanje prioritetnih izmjena iz Poglavlja 27 (izmjena zakona o procjeni uticaja na životnu sredinu, revizija okvira za upravljanje otpadom i usklađivanje zakona o zaštiti prirode sa EU Direktivama o staništima i pticama) radi primjene ubrzane parlamentarne procedure
Uspostavljanje posebne parlamentarne radne grupe za zakonodavno usklađivanje u okviru Poglavlja 27, sa jasnim rokovima i kvartalnim izvještavanjem o napretku
Obavezivanje da svako zatvaranje pristupnog poglavlja bude praćeno ocjenom napretka u Poglavlju 27, kako bi se očuvala politička vidljivost usklađenosti sa standardima zaštite životne sredine
expected_benefits_mne: Ubrzani napredak ka privremenim i završnim mjerilima iz Poglavlja 27
Demonstracija Evropskoj komisiji da Crna Gora pristupa usklađivanju sa ekološkim pravnim tekovinama EU s jednakom ozbiljnošću kao i ostalim poglavljima
Smanjenje rizika da usklađenost u oblasti životne sredine postane glavni uski grlo u cjelokupnom procesu pristupanja EU
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Umjereno izvodljivo. Kapacitet za izradu zakonodavnih akata postoji u okviru Ministarstva i pratećih agencija, međutim politička volja i parlamentarni raspored ostaju ključna ograničenja. Presedan iz Poglavlja 2 pokazuje da su ubrzane procedure dostupne kada postoji odgovarajuća politička motivacija.

assessments.summary_mne: Ova odluka se tiče Poglavlja 2 EU integracija (Sloboda kretanja radnika) i zakona o socijalnoj zaštiti, što izlazi van direktnog mandata Ministarstva životne sredine. Iako Ministarstvo pozdravlja svaki napredak u procesu pristupanja EU, jer gradi institucionalni zamah ka zatvaranju svih poglavlja, uključujući Poglavlje 27 (Životna sredina i klimatske promjene), ova konkretna zakonodavna izmjena nema direktnih ekoloških implikacija. Odluka ne unapređuje niti ometa zaštitu životne sredine, upravljanje obalnim područjem, upravljanje otpadom niti klimatsku politiku.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ova izmjena zakona o socijalnoj zaštiti, usmjerena ka zatvaranju Poglavlja 2, nema direktnog uticaja na životnu sredinu. Ministarstvo životne sredine ocjenjuje je kao neutralnu, ali napominje da bi uporedivu zakonodavnu hitnost trebalo usmjeriti ka znatno zahtjevnijim mjerilima Poglavlja 27, gdje se Crna Gora suočava sa značajnim nedostacima u pogledu usklađenosti.
key_concerns_mne: Nema direktne ekološke relevantnosti, što znači da ova odluka ne doprinosi usklađenosti sa Poglavljem 27
Kontrast između brzog djelovanja u okviru Poglavlja 2 i sporog napretka u ispunjavanju ekoloških mjerila Poglavlja 27 nameće pitanja o zakonodavnim prioritetima
Zakonodavstvo iz oblasti životne sredine koje je na čekanju, kao što su izmjene Zakona o procjeni uticaja na životnu sredinu i Zakona o upravljanju otpadom, i dalje čeka parlamentarnu pažnju
Privremena mjerila Crne Gore za Poglavlje 27 iz 2024. godine ostaju djelimično neispunjena, posebno u pogledu kvaliteta vazduha, infrastrukture za otpad i zaštite prirode
recommendations_mne: Primijeniti istu zakonodavnu hitnost pokazanu za Poglavlje 2 na propise koji čekaju usvajanje u okviru Poglavlja 27, uključujući izmjene Zakona o zaštiti životne sredine i Zakona o zaštiti prirode
Iskoristiti zamah od zatvaranja Poglavlja 2 kako bi se unaprijedila parlamentarna rasprava o prenošenju Paketa EU o kružnoj ekonomiji u crnogorski pravni sistem
Obezbijediti da buduće izmjene vezane za slobodu kretanja uzimaju u obzir implikacije prostornog planiranja u primorskim opštinama s visokom stopom migracije, kao što su Budva, Kotor i Tivat
Dati prioritet parlamentarnom razmatranju dugo odlagane izmjene Nacionalne strategije za klimatske promjene i pratećeg zakonodavnog okvira

assessments.summary: Equalizing social protection rights for EU, EEA, and Swiss citizens is a fiscally manageable step that carries strategic value for EU accession. The immediate budgetary impact is likely minimal given the small number of EU mobile workers currently residing in Montenegro, but the Ministry of Finance must ensure proper cost modeling, reciprocity enforcement, and safeguards against fiscal exposure as the pool of eligible beneficiaries may grow significantly upon actual EU membership.
assessments.executive_summary: The Ministry of Finance views this decision as a positive and necessary step for EU accession with limited near-term fiscal risk but requiring careful cost containment planning. The primary concern is the absence of a published fiscal impact assessment, which should accompany any amendment expanding entitlement eligibility. We recommend embedding a monitoring and reporting mechanism into the implementing legislation to track uptake and costs over time.
assessments.reasoning:
From a fiscal policy perspective, this amendment is a standard requirement for EU accession alignment under Chapter 2 (Freedom of Movement of Workers) and Directive 2014/54/EU. Montenegro's progress on closing negotiation chapters is directly tied to its credibility with international creditors, EU institutions, and foreign investors. Demonstrating legislative alignment strengthens Montenegro's position in accession negotiations, which in turn supports sovereign credit standing and access to favorable EU pre-accession funding (IPA III allocations).

The immediate budgetary exposure is assessed as low. According to available data, the number of EU/EEA/Swiss citizens residing and working in Montenegro remains relatively small, likely in the low thousands. Social and child protection expenditures in Montenegro's budget (administered through Centres for Social Work) represent a modest share of the overall budget, and the marginal cost of extending eligibility to a small pool of EU mobile workers is unlikely to materially affect the fiscal position in 2026 or 2027.

However, the Ministry notes several areas of concern. First, no fiscal impact assessment has been publicly attached to these amendments. Montenegrin fiscal rules and the Organic Budget Law require that legislative proposals with expenditure implications include a cost estimate. Even if the estimated cost is negligible, the discipline of producing such an assessment matters for institutional credibility and EU benchmarking under Chapter 32 (Financial Control). Second, Montenegro uses the euro without ECB membership or lender-of-last-resort access, meaning any unanticipated expansion of fiscal obligations must be treated with particular caution, as the country cannot monetize deficits. Third, while current exposure is small, the dynamic effect must be considered: as Montenegro advances toward EU membership, the number of EU mobile workers may increase, particularly in tourism, construction, and IT sectors. The fiscal trajectory of this entitlement should be modeled under various migration scenarios.

On the positive side, the decision signals openness to labor mobility, which can attract skilled EU workers to fill gaps in Montenegro's labor market, particularly in sectors facing shortages. This has indirect positive fiscal effects through income tax and social contribution revenues collected from EU workers legally employed in Montenegro. Furthermore, reciprocity provisions under EU law mean that Montenegrin citizens working in EU member states will gain equivalent protections, reducing remittance-related social costs domestically.

The immediate-effect clause (upon publication in the Official Gazette) is standard for EU alignment legislation but does raise a minor operational concern: Centres for Social Work and the Ministry of Labour must have administrative capacity and IT systems ready to process claims from newly eligible individuals without delay. Any administrative bottleneck could generate reputational risk with the European Commission during its assessment of Chapter 2 benchmarks.

Overall, this is a sound legislative move whose fiscal risks are manageable but should not be assumed to be zero. Proper fiscal governance demands that even low-cost measures receive rigorous costing and monitoring.
key_concerns: No published fiscal impact assessment accompanies the amendments, which is inconsistent with sound budgetary practice and EU Chapter 32 expectations.
Montenegro's euroization without ECB membership means any unanticipated growth in social protection obligations cannot be absorbed through monetary policy tools.
Dynamic fiscal exposure could grow significantly as Montenegro approaches EU membership and the number of EU mobile workers increases.
Administrative readiness of Centres for Social Work to process claims from newly eligible EU/EEA/Swiss nationals has not been publicly confirmed.
The immediate-effect provision leaves no transitional period for budgetary or administrative preparation.
recommendations: Require the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs to produce and publish a fiscal impact assessment before final parliamentary adoption, even if the estimated cost is minimal, to comply with sound fiscal governance standards.

Instruct the Budget Directorate to establish a dedicated budget line or sub-line for tracking social protection expenditures attributable to EU/EEA/Swiss nationals, enabling transparent monitoring from day one.
Commission a medium-term fiscal projection (2026-2030) modeling social protection costs under various EU mobile worker migration scenarios (low, medium, high inflows).
Coordinate with the Ministry of Labour to ensure Centres for Social Work have updated IT systems and staff training to process claims from newly eligible individuals without administrative delays.
Ensure that reciprocity mechanisms are actively enforced so that Montenegrin workers in EU member states can effectively access equivalent protections, maximizing the bilateral fiscal benefit.

counter_proposal.title: Fiscally Governed EU Social Rights Alignment
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Finance would support the same legislative amendments but would insist on three additions: a mandatory fiscal impact assessment annexed to the law, a dedicated monitoring budget line for tracking costs attributable to newly eligible beneficiaries, and a statutory annual reporting obligation to Parliament on uptake, costs, and fiscal projections. This approach achieves the same EU alignment objective while embedding fiscal discipline and transparency.
key_changes: Annex a fiscal impact assessment to the amendments before final parliamentary vote, as required by sound budgetary practice.
Create a dedicated budget sub-line under the social protection envelope to isolate and track costs related to EU/EEA/Swiss national beneficiaries.

Add a statutory clause requiring the Ministry of Labour to submit an annual report to Parliament and the Ministry of Finance on the number of beneficiaries, total expenditure, and three-year cost projections.
Include a provision for a fiscal review clause that triggers reassessment if annual costs exceed a defined threshold (e.g., 0.05% of GDP).
expected_benefits: Full compliance with EU Chapter 2 requirements while simultaneously strengthening Chapter 32 (Financial Control) credentials.
Transparent cost tracking from inception, avoiding the common problem of discovering fiscal exposure only after costs have accumulated.
Enhanced credibility with the European Commission by demonstrating that Montenegro approaches accession reforms with fiscal rigor.
Early warning mechanism through the fiscal review clause to prevent unanticipated budgetary pressure.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. These additions are procedural and institutional in nature, requiring no additional legislation beyond minor amendments to the proposed text. The fiscal impact assessment can be prepared within weeks by the Budget Directorate in coordination with the Ministry of Labour. The monitoring budget line is an administrative action within the annual budget process. None of these changes would delay Chapter 2 closure.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Usklađivanje socijalnih prava EU pod fiskalnim upravljanjem
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo finansija podržalo bi iste zakonodavne izmjene, ali bi insistiralo na tri dopune: obaveznoj procjeni fiskalnog uticaja priloženoj uz zakon, namjenskoj budžetskoj liniji za praćenje troškova koji se mogu pripisati novim korisnicima prava, te zakonskoj obavezi godišnjeg izvještavanja Parlamentu o ostvarenom obuhvatu, troškovima i fiskalnim projekcijama. Ovaj pristup ostvaruje isti cilj usklađivanja s EU, uz istovremeno ugrađivanje fiskalne discipline i transparentnosti.
key_changes_mne: Priložiti procjenu fiskalnog uticaja uz izmjene prije konačnog glasanja u Parlamentu, u skladu sa zahtjevima zdrave budžetske prakse.
Uspostaviti namjensku budžetsku podliniju u okviru omotnice socijalne zaštite radi izdvajanja i praćenja troškova vezanih za korisnike koji su državljani EU/EEA/Švajcarske.

Dodati zakonsku odredbu kojom se Ministarstvo rada obavezuje da godišnje podnosi izvještaj Parlamentu i Ministarstvu finansija o broju korisnika, ukupnim rashodima i projekcijama troškova za trogodišnji period.
Uključiti odredbu o klauzuli fiskalnog preispitivanja koja pokreće ponovnu procjenu ukoliko godišnji troškovi prekorače utvrđeni prag (npr. 0,05% BDP-a).
expected_benefits_mne: Potpuna usklađenost sa zahtjevima Poglavlja 2 EU, uz istovremeno jačanje kredibiliteta u okviru Poglavlja 32 (Finansijska kontrola).
Transparentno praćenje troškova od samog početka, čime se izbjegava uobičajeni problem otkrivanja fiskalne izloženosti tek nakon što su se troškovi nagomilali.
Veći kredibilitet pred Evropskom komisijom, demonstriranjem da Crna Gora pristupa reformama u procesu pristupanja s fiskalnom rigoroznošću.
Mehanizam ranog upozoravanja putem klauzule fiskalnog preispitivanja, u cilju sprječavanja nepredviđenih budžetskih pritisaka.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka. Ove dopune su proceduralne i institucionalne prirode i ne zahtijevaju dodatno zakonodavstvo izvan manjih izmjena predloženog teksta. Procjenu fiskalnog uticaja može pripremiti Direktorat za budžet u koordinaciji s Ministarstvom rada u roku od nekoliko sedmica. Namjenska budžetska linija za praćenje predstavlja administrativnu mjeru u okviru godišnjeg budžetskog procesa. Nijedna od ovih izmjena ne bi odložila zatvaranje Poglavlja 2.

assessments.summary_mne: Izjednačavanje prava socijalne zaštite za građane EU, EEA i Švajcarske je fiskalno upravljiv korak koji nosi stratešku vrijednost za pristupanje EU. Neposredni budžetski uticaj vjerovatno je minimalan s obzirom na mali broj mobilnih radnika iz EU koji trenutno borave u Crnoj Gori, ali Ministarstvo finansija mora osigurati odgovarajuće modeliranje troškova, primjenu principa reciprociteta i zaštitne mehanizme od fiskalnog rizika, jer broj potencijalnih korisnika može značajno porasti stvarnim ulaskom u EU.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ministarstvo finansija ovaj korak smatra pozitivnim i neophodnim za pristupanje EU, uz ograničen fiskalni rizik u kratkom roku, ali uz potrebu za pažljivim planiranjem kontrole troškova. Primarni problem je odsustvo objavljene fiskalne procjene uticaja, koja bi trebalo da prati svaku izmjenu kojom se proširuje krug korisnika prava. Preporučujemo da se u provedbeno zakonodavstvo ugradi mehanizam praćenja i izvještavanja radi evidentiranja korišćenja prava i troškova tokom vremena.
key_concerns_mne: Uz izmjene nije objavljena fiskalna procjena uticaja, što nije u skladu sa dobrom budžetskom praksom i očekivanjima poglavlja 32 EU.
Euroizacija Crne Gore bez članstva u ECB-u znači da se eventualni neočekivani rast obaveza socijalne zaštite ne može apsorbovati putem instrumenata monetarne politike.
Dinamična fiskalna izloženost mogla bi značajno porasti kako se Crna Gora bude približavala članstvu u EU i kako bude rastao broj mobilnih radnika iz EU.
Administrativna spremnost Centara za socijalni rad za obradu zahtjeva novoprihvatljivih državljana EU/EEA/Švajcarske nije javno potvrđena.
Odredba o neposrednoj primjeni ne ostavlja nikakav prelazni period za budžetske ili administrativne pripreme.
recommendations_mne: Obavezati Ministarstvo rada i socijalnog staranja da pripremi i objavi fiskalnu procjenu uticaja prije konačnog usvajanja u parlamentu, čak i ako su procijenjeni troškovi minimalni, kako bi se ispunili standardi dobre fiskalne uprave.

Naložiti Upravi za budžet da uspostavi namjensku budžetsku stavku ili podstavku za praćenje rashoda socijalne zaštite koji se mogu pripisati državljanima EU/EEA/Švajcarske, kako bi se od prvog dana omogućilo transparentno praćenje.
Naručiti srednjoročnu fiskalnu projekciju (2026–2030) koja modelira troškove socijalne zaštite u različitim scenarijima migracije mobilnih radnika iz EU (niski, srednji i visoki prilivi).

Koordinisati sa Ministarstvom rada kako bi se osiguralo da Centri za socijalni rad raspolažu ažuriranim IT sistemima i obučenim kadrom za obradu zahtjeva novoprihvatljivih lica bez administrativnih kašnjenja.
Osigurati aktivnu primjenu mehanizama reciprociteta kako bi crnogorski radnici u državama članicama EU mogli efektivno ostvarivati odgovarajuća prava, čime se maksimizuje obostrana fiskalna korist.

assessments.summary: The proposed amendments to the Law on Social and Child Protection represent a sound and necessary step toward EU accession by transposing Directive 2014/54/EU into Montenegrin law, directly supporting the closure of Chapter 2. The initiative is constitutionally permissible, advances the non-discrimination principle, and aligns with Montenegro's international obligations. However, the Ministry of Justice identifies concerns regarding the legislative process, the absence of judicial enforcement mechanisms, and the need for broader legal coherence across related statutes.
assessments.executive_summary: This is a welcome legislative step toward EU accession that correctly addresses nationality-based discrimination in social protection. The Ministry of Justice recommends strengthening the amendments with explicit judicial remedies for aggrieved workers and ensuring simultaneous harmonization of related laws to avoid legal fragmentation.
assessments.reasoning:
From a constitutional standpoint, the amendments are consistent with the Constitution of Montenegro, particularly Article 8 (principle of reciprocity and alignment with international law), Article 17 (equality before the law), and Article 67 (right to social protection). The Constitution permits equal treatment of foreign nationals where established by international agreement or domestic law, and Montenegro's Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the EU already envisions such alignment. There is no constitutional barrier to extending social and child protection rights to EU, EEA, and Swiss citizens on a non-discriminatory basis.

Regarding rule of law, the decision to pursue this through parliamentary amendments rather than executive decree is appropriate and reflects proper legislative procedure. However, the Ministry notes that the immediate entry into force upon publication in the Official Gazette raises concerns. Best legislative practice, and the standard approach under Montenegrin law, typically provides a vacatio legis period (usually eight days minimum) to allow institutions, courts, and citizens to prepare for new obligations. Immediate effect should be reserved for genuinely urgent matters, and while EU accession is a national priority, the social protection system requires administrative preparation to implement these changes effectively.

On human rights, the amendments are strongly positive. They directly implement the principle of non-discrimination on the basis of nationality, which is a cornerstone of both the European Convention on Human Rights (Protocol 12, to which Montenegro is a party) and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. This strengthens Montenegro's compliance with ECHR jurisprudence and advances the position of mobile workers who currently face legal uncertainty regarding their entitlements.

Concerning legal harmonization with the EU acquis, the transposition of Directive 2014/54/EU is directly relevant to Chapter 2 benchmarks. The European Commission has consistently flagged Montenegro's incomplete alignment in this area. However, the Ministry of Justice observes that Directive 2014/54/EU is not solely about substantive rights; it also requires Member States to establish or designate bodies for the promotion, analysis, monitoring, and support of equal treatment of EU workers and their family members (Article 4 of the Directive). The amendments as reported appear to focus on substantive entitlements without addressing these institutional and procedural requirements. This is a significant gap that could prevent the European Commission from recognizing full transposition.

On judicial independence and enforcement, the Ministry is concerned that the amendments do not appear to include provisions for effective judicial remedies. Directive 2014/54/EU explicitly requires that workers who believe they have been subject to discrimination have access to judicial process. The amendments should specify which courts have jurisdiction over disputes arising from denial of social protection benefits to EU workers, and should include provisions on burden of proof consistent with EU anti-discrimination law (shifting the burden to the respondent once a prima facie case is established).

Regarding anti-corruption, while this decision is not directly an anti-corruption measure, the extension of social protection rights to a new category of beneficiaries creates new administrative processes that must be designed with integrity safeguards. Clear eligibility criteria, transparent decision-making procedures, and administrative appeal mechanisms are essential to prevent discretionary denial or corrupt gatekeeping of benefits.

Finally, the Ministry notes that amending only the Law on Social and Child Protection may create legal fragmentation. EU worker mobility rights intersect with employment law, tax law, health insurance law, and pension law. If those statutes are not simultaneously amended, EU workers may find themselves with social protection rights on paper but unable to access them in practice due to conflicting provisions in adjacent legislation.
key_concerns: Immediate entry into force without a vacatio legis period may hinder proper institutional preparation and undermine legal certainty.
The amendments appear to lack provisions for designating a body to promote and monitor equal treatment of EU workers, as required by Article 4 of Directive 2014/54/EU.
No explicit judicial remedy or enforcement mechanism is included for EU workers who are denied benefits, which is a core requirement of the Directive.
Amending only the Law on Social and Child Protection risks legal fragmentation, as related statutes on employment, health insurance, and pensions may contain conflicting or non-harmonized provisions.
Absence of provisions on burden of proof in discrimination cases, which should be aligned with EU anti-discrimination standards.
Administrative capacity of centres for social work to process claims from a new category of beneficiaries has not been publicly assessed.
recommendations: Include a minimum eight-day vacatio legis period to allow institutions to prepare implementation procedures and train staff.
Add provisions designating or establishing a body responsible for promoting and monitoring equal treatment of EU workers, in line with Article 4 of Directive 2014/54/EU.
Incorporate explicit judicial remedy provisions specifying court jurisdiction and procedural rules for discrimination claims by EU workers.
Adopt a burden-of-proof provision consistent with EU anti-discrimination directives, shifting the burden to the respondent once a prima facie case of nationality-based discrimination is shown.
Conduct a parallel review and amendment of the Law on Health Insurance, Law on Pension and Disability Insurance, and Labour Law to ensure coherent transposition across all relevant statutes.
Issue a Government action plan with clear timelines for administrative capacity building in centres for social work.
Engage the Protector of Human Rights and Freedoms (Ombudsman) as part of the institutional framework for monitoring equal treatment of EU workers.

counter_proposal.title: Comprehensive Transposition Package for Chapter 2 Compliance
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than a standalone amendment to a single law, the Ministry of Justice would propose a coordinated legislative package simultaneously amending the Law on Social and Child Protection, the Labour Law, the Law on Health Insurance, and the Law on Pension and Disability Insurance, accompanied by a dedicated enforcement and monitoring framework. This would ensure full and verifiable transposition of Directive 2014/54/EU and strengthen Montenegro's negotiating position for closing Chapter 2.
key_changes: Bundle amendments across all four relevant statutes into a single legislative package to ensure coherence and avoid legal gaps.
Designate the Ombudsman institution as the body for promotion and monitoring of equal treatment of EU workers, with a dedicated unit and reporting obligations.
Insert explicit judicial remedy provisions including designated court jurisdiction, expedited proceedings for discrimination claims, and aligned burden-of-proof rules.
Provide a 15-day vacatio legis period with a Government instruction to centres for social work on implementation procedures.
Establish a monitoring and reporting mechanism requiring annual reports to Parliament on the implementation of EU worker equal treatment rights.
expected_benefits: Full rather than partial transposition of Directive 2014/54/EU, significantly increasing the probability that the European Commission will recognize Chapter 2 benchmarks as met.
Legal certainty for EU workers and Montenegrin institutions through coherent rules across all relevant statutes.
Stronger rule-of-law credentials by including enforceable judicial remedies and independent monitoring.
Reduced risk of ECHR complaints by ensuring effective domestic remedies for nationality-based discrimination.
Enhanced credibility in EU accession negotiations by demonstrating institutional capacity alongside legislative alignment.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible within a 60 to 90 day legislative timeline. The additional amendments to related laws are largely technical and can be drafted in parallel. Designating the Ombudsman requires coordination but no new institution. The main constraint is political will to pursue a comprehensive approach rather than a piecemeal one, but the gains in EU accession credibility would justify the additional effort.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Sveobuhvatni paket transpozicije za usklađenost sa Poglavljem 2
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto pojedinačne izmjene jednog zakona, Ministarstvo pravde bi predložilo koordinisani zakonodavni paket kojim se istovremeno mijenjaju Zakon o socijalnoj i dječjoj zaštiti, Zakon o radu, Zakon o zdravstvenom osiguranju i Zakon o penzijskom i invalidskom osiguranju, praćen posebnim okvirom za sprovođenje i praćenje. Time bi se osigurala potpuna i provjerljiva transpozicija Direktive 2014/54/EU i ojačala pregovaračka pozicija Crne Gore u pogledu zatvaranja Poglavlja 2.
key_changes_mne: Objediniti izmjene sva četiri relevantna zakona u jedan zakonodavni paket radi osiguranja koherentnosti i izbjegavanja pravnih praznina.
Odrediti instituciju Zaštitnika ljudskih prava i sloboda kao tijelo nadležno za promociju i praćenje jednakog tretmana radnika iz EU, s posebnom organizacionom jedinicom i obavezama izvještavanja.
Uvesti izričite odredbe o sudskoj zaštiti, uključujući određivanje nadležnih sudova, ubrzani postupak za tužbe zbog diskriminacije i usklađena pravila o teretu dokazivanja.
Predvidjeti vacatio legis period od 15 dana uz uputstvo Vlade centrima za socijalni rad o postupcima primjene.
Uspostaviti mehanizam praćenja i izvještavanja koji podrazumijeva godišnje izvještaje Skupštini o primjeni prava na jednaki tretman radnika iz EU.
expected_benefits_mne: Potpuna, a ne djelimična transpozicija Direktive 2014/54/EU, čime se značajno povećava vjerovatnoća da će Evropska komisija prepoznati ispunjenost mjerila za Poglavlje 2.
Pravna sigurnost za radnike iz EU i crnogorske institucije kroz koherentna pravila u svim relevantnim zakonima.
Jači kredibilitet u oblasti vladavine prava uvođenjem izvršivih sudskih lijekova i nezavisnog nadzora.
Smanjen rizik od pritužbi ESLJP-u osiguranjem djelotvornih unutrašnjih pravnih lijekova u slučajevima diskriminacije zasnovane na državljanstvu.
Pojačan kredibilitet u pregovorima o pristupanju EU demonstriranjem institucionalnih kapaciteta uz zakonodavno usklađivanje.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Umjereno ostvarivo u zakonodavnom roku od 60 do 90 dana. Dodatne izmjene povezanih zakona su uglavnom tehničke prirode i mogu se izrađivati paralelno. Određivanje Zaštitnika zahtijeva koordinaciju, ali ne i osnivanje nove institucije. Glavni ograničavajući faktor je politička volja da se pristupi sveobuhvatnom, a ne parcijalnom pristupu, no dobici u smislu kredibilnosti u procesu pristupanja EU opravdavaju dodatni napor.

assessments.summary_mne: Predložene izmjene i dopune Zakona o socijalnoj i dječjoj zaštiti predstavljaju smislen i neophodan korak ka pristupanju EU, prenosom Direktive 2014/54/EU u crnogorsko zakonodavstvo, čime se neposredno podržava zatvaranje Poglavlja 2. Inicijativa je ustavno dopustiva, unapređuje načelo nediskriminacije i usklađena je s međunarodnim obavezama Crne Gore. Međutim, Ministarstvo pravde iznosi zabrinutosti u pogledu zakonodavnog postupka, odsustva mehanizama sudskog izvršenja i potrebe za širom pravnom koherentnošću između srodnih propisa.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ovo je dobrodošao zakonodavni korak ka pristupanju EU koji na ispravan način adresira diskriminaciju zasnovanu na državljanstvu u oblasti socijalne zaštite. Ministarstvo pravde preporučuje jačanje izmjena izričitim sudskim pravnim sredstvima za oštećene radnike, kao i istovremenu harmonizaciju srodnih zakona radi sprečavanja pravne fragmentacije.
key_concerns_mne: Neposredno stupanje na snagu bez perioda vacatio legis može otežati odgovarajuću institucionalnu pripremu i ugroziti pravnu sigurnost.
Čini se da izmjenama nedostaju odredbe o određivanju tijela nadležnog za promovisanje i praćenje jednakog tretmana radnika iz EU, kako to zahtijeva član 4 Direktive 2014/54/EU.
Za radnike iz EU kojima su uskraćene naknade nije predviđeno nijedno izričito sudsko pravno sredstvo ni mehanizam izvršenja, što predstavlja temeljni zahtjev Direktive.

Izmjena isključivo Zakona o socijalnoj i dječjoj zaštiti nosi rizik od pravne fragmentacije, s obzirom na to da srodni propisi o zapošljavanju, zdravstvenom osiguranju i penzijama mogu sadržavati suprotne ili neusklađene odredbe.
Odsustvo odredaba o teretu dokazivanja u slučajevima diskriminacije, koje bi trebalo uskladiti sa standardima EU u oblasti borbe protiv diskriminacije.
Administrativni kapaciteti centara za socijalni rad za obradu zahtjeva nove kategorije korisnika javno nisu procijenjeni.
recommendations_mne: Uvesti minimalni period vacatio legis od osam dana kako bi institucije mogle pripremiti procedure sprovođenja i obučiti osoblje.
Dodati odredbe kojima se određuje ili osniva tijelo odgovorno za promovisanje i praćenje jednakog tretmana radnika iz EU, u skladu s članom 4 Direktive 2014/54/EU.
Ugraditi izričite odredbe o sudskim pravnim sredstvima, kojima se preciziraju nadležnost suda i procesna pravila za tužbe radnika iz EU u slučajevima diskriminacije.

Usvojiti odredbu o teretu dokazivanja u skladu s direktivama EU o borbi protiv diskriminacije, kojom se teret dokazivanja prebacuje na tuženu stranu čim tužilac učini vjerovatnim postojanje diskriminacije zasnovane na državljanstvu.

Sprovesti paralelno preispitivanje i izmjenu Zakona o zdravstvenom osiguranju, Zakona o penzijskom i invalidskom osiguranju i Zakona o radu radi obezbjeđivanja koherentnog prenosa propisa kroz sve relevantne zakone.
Donijeti vladini akcioni plan s jasnim rokovima za izgradnju administrativnih kapaciteta u centrima za socijalni rad.
Uključiti Zaštitnika ljudskih prava i sloboda (Ombudsmana) u institucionalni okvir za praćenje jednakog tretmana radnika iz EU.

assessments.summary: This legislative amendment is a welcome and necessary step toward closing EU accession Chapter 2, and the Ministry of Interior views it positively as it signals continued alignment with the EU acquis. However, the decision carries significant downstream implications for the Ministry's operational domains, particularly in identity verification, residence registration systems, interoperability of social protection databases with police and border management systems, and the potential for fraudulent claims that could be exploited by organized crime networks. The immediate entry into force raises concerns about administrative readiness across institutions that the Ministry of Interior must coordinate with.
assessments.executive_summary: The Ministry of Interior supports this EU-aligned legislative step but warns that immediate implementation without upgrading identity verification, interagency data-sharing systems, and administrative capacity at local social welfare centers creates vulnerabilities. The top recommendation is to condition operational rollout on completion of IT system integration between the Ministry of Labour, the Ministry of Interior's residence registration databases, and the Police Directorate's records.
assessments.reasoning:
From the perspective of the Ministry of Interior, this decision is primarily a matter of social policy and EU accession compliance under Chapter 2 (Freedom of Movement of Workers). It does not directly amend police powers, border legislation, or public safety frameworks. However, the Ministry has several legitimate operational concerns that must be addressed for the decision to function properly and securely.

First, regarding identity verification and residence status: granting equal social protection rights to EU, EEA, and Swiss nationals requires a robust system for verifying the identity and legal residence status of claimants. The Ministry of Interior, through the Directorate for Administrative Internal Affairs (Direkcija za upravne unutrasnje poslove), is responsible for issuing temporary and permanent residence permits to foreign nationals. The current system for processing and verifying residence of EU nationals, while functional, was designed for a smaller caseload. If Montenegro closes Chapter 2 and the broader freedom of movement framework expands, the volume of verifications will increase. The Ministry must ensure its databases are interoperable with the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare's systems to allow real-time verification of residence status when social benefits are claimed.

Second, regarding fraud prevention and organized crime: EU-wide experience shows that equal access to social protection benefits can be exploited through identity fraud, fictitious employment schemes, and benefit tourism organized by criminal networks. Countries such as Belgium, Germany, and the UK have documented cases where organized groups systematically exploited social welfare systems using forged documents or shell companies. Montenegro's organized crime environment, which remains a key concern under EU accession Chapter 24, must be factored in. The Police Directorate (Uprava policije) should be prepared with analytical capacity to detect patterns of fraudulent claims, and the Special State Prosecutor's Office should be briefed on potential new typologies of social welfare fraud involving cross-border elements.

Third, regarding administrative capacity: the immediate entry into force upon publication in the Official Gazette is a concern. While political urgency around closing Chapter 2 is understandable, the Ministry of Interior notes that local-level institutions, including Centers for Social Work (Centri za socijalni rad), police administrative units, and municipal offices, may not be prepared to process new categories of claimants. Training on document recognition for EU identity documents, understanding of different EU residence statuses, and coordination protocols between social welfare and interior affairs at the local level should be established before or concurrent with implementation.

Fourth, regarding border management and Schengen preparation: this decision is consistent with Montenegro's broader trajectory toward Schengen alignment. The Ministry of Interior notes that as freedom of movement provisions are harmonized, the pressure increases on border management systems to accurately track entries, exits, and durations of stay. The integration of Montenegro into EU information systems such as SIS II, VIS, and eventually the Entry/Exit System becomes even more critical. The decision reinforces the need for the Ministry's ongoing investments in border infrastructure and digital systems.

Finally, the decision is a positive signal for EU accession and the Ministry of Interior supports it as part of the broader reform agenda. However, the Ministry insists that legislative alignment must be accompanied by institutional and operational readiness to prevent the creation of vulnerabilities.
key_concerns: Immediate entry into force may outpace administrative readiness at local Centers for Social Work and municipal offices to verify EU nationals' residence status and process new benefit claims
Lack of confirmed interoperability between the Ministry of Interior's residence permit databases and the social protection information systems managed by the Ministry of Labour
Risk of organized criminal exploitation through identity fraud, fictitious employment, or shell company schemes to extract social benefits, a pattern documented in multiple EU member states
Insufficient training for frontline administrative and police staff on recognition and verification of EU identity documents and varying categories of EU residence status
No explicit mention of a fraud detection and monitoring mechanism to track anomalous patterns in benefit claims by newly eligible populations
Increased pressure on the Police Directorate's analytical units to monitor a new category of potential cross-border financial fraud without corresponding resource allocation
recommendations: Establish a mandatory interoperability protocol between the Ministry of Interior's residence registration system and the social protection benefits database before full operational rollout, even if the law enters into force immediately
Task the Police Directorate's Criminal Intelligence Unit with developing a risk assessment on potential fraud typologies related to cross-border social benefit exploitation in the Montenegrin context

Coordinate with the Ministry of Labour to deliver joint training to Centers for Social Work staff on EU identity document verification, residence status categories, and red flag indicators for fraudulent claims

Request that the European Commission's TAIEX or bilateral partners provide technical assistance on fraud prevention frameworks used in EU member states for social benefit systems open to mobile workers

Integrate this legislative change into the Ministry of Interior's Chapter 24 action plan reporting, as enforcement of anti-fraud measures in social protection is directly relevant to the fight against organized crime and corruption
Ensure the National Bureau for the Prevention of Money Laundering is briefed on new potential proceeds-of-crime typologies related to social welfare fraud by organized groups

counter_proposal.title: Phased Implementation with Security Readiness Conditions
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Interior proposes that while the law should be adopted as drafted to maintain political momentum on Chapter 2, its operational application should be accompanied by a 90-day implementation protocol during which interagency data-sharing systems are verified, frontline staff are trained, and a fraud monitoring framework is established. This does not require amending the law itself but rather issuing a Government Conclusion or bylaw that mandates specific readiness conditions for processing agencies.
key_changes: Issue a Government Conclusion mandating that the Ministry of Interior and Ministry of Labour complete database interoperability testing within 60 days of publication
Require all Centers for Social Work to complete a training module on EU document verification and residence status before processing claims from EU nationals
Establish a joint Interior-Labour working group to monitor the first 12 months of implementation and report quarterly on claim volumes, rejection rates, and fraud indicators
Direct the Police Directorate to produce a classified risk assessment on cross-border social benefit fraud within 90 days
expected_benefits: Maintains full EU accession compliance and political momentum on closing Chapter 2
Reduces the risk of fraud exploitation during the vulnerable early implementation period
Builds institutional capacity that will be needed for broader freedom of movement provisions as accession progresses
Demonstrates to the European Commission that Montenegro pairs legislative alignment with operational enforcement capacity, strengthening the Chapter 24 narrative
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. This approach requires no legislative amendment and can be implemented through existing government coordination mechanisms. The 90-day protocol is a standard EU implementation practice and would be well received by the European Commission as evidence of institutional maturity.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Fazna implementacija s uvjetima operativne spremnosti u oblasti sigurnosti
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova predlaže da se zakon usvoji u predloženom obliku radi očuvanja političkog zamaha u Poglavlju 2, ali da njegova operativna primjena bude praćena 90-dnevnim protokolom implementacije tokom kojeg će se verificirati međuagencijski sistemi razmjene podataka, obučiti osoblje na terenu i uspostaviti okvir za praćenje prevara. Za to nije potrebno mijenjati sam zakon, već donijeti Zaključak Vlade ili podzakonski akt kojim se propisuju konkretni uvjeti operativne spremnosti za nadležne organe.
key_changes_mne: Donijeti Zaključak Vlade kojim se Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova i Ministarstvo rada obavezuju da u roku od 60 dana od dana objavljivanja završe testiranje interoperabilnosti baza podataka
Obavezati sve Centre za socijalni rad da završe modul obuke o verifikaciji dokumenata EU i statusu boravka prije obrade zahtjeva državljana EU

Uspostaviti zajednički radni tim Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova i Ministarstva rada radi praćenja prvih 12 mjeseci implementacije i tromjesečnog izvještavanja o obimu zahtjeva, stopama odbijanja i pokazateljima prevara
Naložiti Upravi policije da u roku od 90 dana izradi povjerljivu procjenu rizika od prekograničnih prevara u oblasti socijalnih naknada
expected_benefits_mne: Održava potpunu usklađenost s EU acquis-em i politički zamah u zatvaranju Poglavlja 2
Smanjuje rizik od zloupotreba putem prevara tokom osjetljivog ranog perioda implementacije
Izgrađuje institucionalne kapacitete koji će biti neophodni za šire odredbe o slobodi kretanja kako proces pristupanja bude napredovao
Pokazuje Evropskoj komisiji da Crna Gora zakonodavno usklađivanje prati operativnim kapacitetima izvršenja, čime se jača narativ u okviru Poglavlja 24
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka. Ovaj pristup ne zahtijeva zakonodavne izmjene i može se sprovesti kroz postojeće mehanizme vladine koordinacije. 90-dnevni protokol predstavlja standardnu praksu implementacije u EU i Evropska komisija bi ga dočekala pozitivno kao dokaz institucionalne zrelosti.

assessments.summary_mne: Ovaj zakonodavni amandman predstavlja dobrodošao i neophodan korak ka zatvaranju Poglavlja 2 u procesu pristupanja EU, i Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova gleda na njega pozitivno jer signalizira nastavak usklađivanja s pravnom tekovinom EU. Međutim, ova odluka nosi značajne posredne implikacije za operativne domene Ministarstva, posebno u oblasti provjere identiteta, sistema registracije boravišta, interoperabilnosti baza podataka socijalne zaštite s policijskim sistemima i sistemima upravljanja granicom, kao i potencijala za lažne zahtjeve koje bi mogle iskoristiti organizovane kriminalne mreže. Trenutno stupanje na snagu izaziva zabrinutost u pogledu administrativne spremnosti institucija s kojima Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova mora da koordinira.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova podržava ovaj zakonodavni korak usklađen s EU, ali upozorava da trenutna primjena bez unapređenja provjere identiteta, sistema međuagencijske razmjene podataka i administrativnih kapaciteta lokalnih centara za socijalni rad stvara ranjivosti. Ključna preporuka je da se operativna primjena usloviti završetkom integracije IT sistema između Ministarstva rada, baza podataka registracije boravišta Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova i evidencija Uprave policije.
key_concerns_mne: Trenutno stupanje na snagu može prevazići administrativnu spremnost lokalnih centara za socijalni rad i opštinskih službi za provjeru statusa boravišta državljana EU i obradu novih zahtjeva za naknade
Nedostatak potvrđene interoperabilnosti između baza podataka dozvola boravka Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova i informacionih sistema socijalne zaštite kojima upravlja Ministarstvo rada

Rizik od iskorišćavanja od strane organizovanog kriminala putem prevare identiteta, fiktivnog zaposlenja ili šema sa fiktivnim kompanijama radi izvlačenja socijalnih naknada — obrazac dokumentovan u više država članica EU
Nedovoljna obuka za administrativno osoblje i policijske službenike na prvoj liniji u pogledu prepoznavanja i provjere identifikacionih dokumenata EU i različitih kategorija statusa boravišta u EU
Nema izričitog pominjanja mehanizma za otkrivanje prevara i praćenje anomalnih obrazaca u zahtjevima za naknade od strane novoprihvatljivog stanovništva
Povećan pritisak na analitičke jedinice Uprave policije da prate novu kategoriju potencijalnih prekograničnih finansijskih prevara bez odgovarajuće dodjele resursa
recommendations_mne: Uspostaviti obavezan protokol interoperabilnosti između sistema registracije boravišta Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova i baze podataka naknada socijalne zaštite prije pune operativne primjene, čak i ako zakon odmah stupi na snagu

Zadužiti Jedinicu za kriminalnu obavještajnu djelatnost Uprave policije da izradi procjenu rizika o potencijalnim tipologijama prevara u vezi s prekograničnim iskorišćavanjem socijalnih naknada u crnogorskom kontekstu

Koordinisati s Ministarstvom rada radi organizovanja zajedničke obuke za osoblje centara za socijalni rad o provjeri identifikacionih dokumenata EU, kategorijama statusa boravišta i pokazateljima upozorenja za lažne zahtjeve

Zatražiti od TAIEX-a Evropske komisije ili bilateralnih partnera pružanje tehničke pomoći u pogledu okvira za sprečavanje prevara koji se primjenjuju u državama članicama EU za sisteme socijalnih naknada otvorene za mobilne radnike

Integrisati ovu zakonodavnu izmjenu u izvještavanje u okviru akcionog plana Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova za Poglavlje 24, budući da je sprovođenje mjera za borbu protiv prevara u socijalnoj zaštiti direktno relevantno za borbu protiv organizovanog kriminala i korupcije
Osigurati da Zavod za sprečavanje pranja novca bude upoznat s novim potencijalnim tipologijama prihoda stečenih kriminalom u vezi s prevarama u oblasti socijalne zaštite od strane organizovanih grupa

assessments.summary: This parliamentary initiative represents one of the most significant legislative steps Montenegro has taken in recent years toward advancing its EU accession process. By amending the Law on Social and Child Protection to extend equal treatment to EU, EEA, and Swiss citizens, Montenegro directly addresses a core closing benchmark for Chapter 2 (Freedom of Movement of Workers) and demonstrates concrete transposition of EU Directive 2014/54/EU. The Ministry of EU Integration views this as a model of how legislative alignment should proceed across all negotiation chapters.
assessments.executive_summary: The proposed amendments are a strongly positive development that directly targets a closing benchmark for Chapter 2. The key concern is ensuring robust implementation capacity and reciprocity frameworks are in place before the law takes effect. The Ministry recommends pairing this legislative action with institutional strengthening and a clear enforcement mechanism to maximize its impact on the European Commission's next progress assessment.
assessments.reasoning:
Chapter 2 (Freedom of Movement of Workers) has been open since 2014, and the European Commission has consistently noted in its annual progress reports that Montenegro needed to further align its social protection framework with the acquis, particularly regarding non-discrimination of EU mobile workers. Directive 2014/54/EU on measures facilitating the exercise of rights conferred on workers in the context of freedom of movement is a central piece of this chapter's acquis, and its transposition into Montenegrin law has been a longstanding benchmark requirement.

The decision to extend equal social and child protection rights to EU, EEA, and Swiss nationals is legally and politically significant. It signals Montenegro's readiness to accept the obligations of EU membership in one of the four fundamental freedoms -- the free movement of persons. This is not merely a technical adjustment; it reflects a substantive policy commitment that will be scrutinized by the European Commission in its next annual report and in bilateral screening meetings.

From an acquis alignment perspective, the amendments appear well-targeted. Directive 2014/54/EU specifically requires member states to ensure that EU workers and their family members are not discriminated against on grounds of nationality in accessing social advantages, including social protection and child benefits. By embedding this principle in the Law on Social and Child Protection, Montenegro is following the standard transposition pathway used by recent EU member states such as Croatia.

However, the Ministry notes several areas requiring attention. First, legislative transposition alone does not satisfy the European Commission. The Commission consistently evaluates implementation capacity -- meaning administrative readiness, staff training, IT systems for cross-border coordination of social security (linking to Regulation 883/2004 on coordination of social security systems), and accessible complaint mechanisms. Montenegro must demonstrate that the Employment Agency, Centres for Social Work, and relevant municipal bodies are prepared to process claims from EU nationals without delay or discrimination.

Second, the immediate entry into force upon publication in the Official Gazette, while demonstrating urgency and political will, raises concerns about whether implementing institutions have been given adequate preparation time. A phased implementation with clear milestones would have been more prudent from an administrative capacity standpoint.

Third, the amendments should be evaluated in the broader context of Chapter 2 benchmarks, which also include alignment with Regulation 492/2011 on freedom of movement for workers within the Union, and establishment of a body to promote equal treatment. The Ministry would want to verify that this legislative action is part of a comprehensive action plan for Chapter 2 closure rather than an isolated measure.

Regarding regional cooperation, this move positions Montenegro ahead of Serbia and Albania in Chapter 2 alignment, reinforcing Montenegro's traditional role as the frontrunner among Western Balkans candidate countries. This differentiation is strategically valuable in Brussels, particularly as the European Commission considers the credibility-based approach to enlargement.

On IPA funding implications, successful legislative alignment under Chapter 2 strengthens Montenegro's position in IPA III programming, particularly under Window 1 (Rule of Law, Fundamental Rights, and Democracy) and Window 4 (Competitiveness and Inclusive Growth), where social inclusion and labor mobility projects could attract additional EU financing for implementation support.
key_concerns: Immediate entry into force may outpace administrative readiness of Centres for Social Work and municipal bodies to process claims from EU nationals

Legislative transposition alone will not satisfy the European Commission without demonstrated implementation capacity, trained staff, and operational IT systems for cross-border social security coordination
The amendments must be part of a comprehensive Chapter 2 closure strategy that also addresses Regulation 492/2011 and the establishment of an equal treatment body, not an isolated legislative act
Fiscal impact assessment appears absent -- the budgetary implications of extending social and child protection benefits to a new category of beneficiaries should be quantified and disclosed
Reciprocity frameworks with EU member states for Montenegrin nationals working abroad need to be addressed in parallel to ensure balanced obligations
Risk that the law is perceived as a symbolic gesture if enforcement and complaint mechanisms are not operationalized promptly
recommendations: Develop and publish a detailed implementation roadmap within 60 days of enactment, including staff training schedules, IT system upgrades for cross-border coordination under Regulation 883/2004, and public information campaigns
Establish or designate a formal equal treatment body as required under Directive 2014/54/EU Article 4, with clear mandate, resources, and independence to handle complaints from EU mobile workers
Conduct a fiscal impact assessment and present it to Parliament before the amendments take effect, ensuring budget lines are allocated in the 2026 supplementary budget if necessary

Coordinate with the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare to align this amendment with parallel reforms needed under Regulation 492/2011 and present a unified Chapter 2 closure package to the European Commission
Brief the European Commission's DG NEAR and the relevant chapter screening team proactively to ensure this legislative step is registered in the next progress report and interim benchmarks assessment
Request targeted IPA III technical assistance for institutional capacity building in cross-border social security coordination

counter_proposal.title: Comprehensive Chapter 2 Closure Package with Phased Implementation
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than enacting this amendment in isolation with immediate effect, the Ministry of EU Integration would have proposed a comprehensive Chapter 2 closure package that bundles the social protection amendments with parallel alignment measures under Regulation 492/2011, establishment of an equal treatment body under Directive 2014/54/EU Article 4, and a 90-day phased implementation period. This package would be presented to the European Commission as a unified closure proposal, maximizing its diplomatic and benchmarking impact.
key_changes: Bundle the social protection amendments with amendments ensuring full transposition of Regulation 492/2011 on access to employment and working conditions
Include provisions establishing a dedicated equal treatment body with independent mandate and adequate staffing as required by Directive 2014/54/EU Article 4
Replace immediate entry into force with a 90-day phased implementation to allow institutional preparation, staff training, and IT system readiness
Attach a mandatory fiscal impact assessment and require annual reporting to Parliament on the number of EU nationals accessing benefits
Include a coordination clause linking this law to future alignment with Regulation 883/2004 on social security coordination
expected_benefits: Stronger negotiating position with the European Commission by presenting a complete Chapter 2 closure package rather than piecemeal legislation
Reduced risk of implementation failures that could be flagged as shortcomings in the next progress report
Greater fiscal transparency and parliamentary oversight of the budgetary impact
Faster and more credible path to actually closing Chapter 2, which would be a landmark achievement for Montenegro's accession process
Better positioning for IPA III funding requests tied to a coherent institutional strengthening plan
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. The additional measures proposed are already identified in the European Commission's screening reports and would require 2-3 months of additional drafting work. The 90-day implementation delay is modest and would not materially slow accession progress while significantly reducing implementation risk. Political will clearly exists given the parliamentary initiative, so the main requirement is coordination across the Ministry of Labour, Ministry of Finance, and the EU Integration Office.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Sveobuhvatni paket za zatvaranje Poglavlja 2 s faznom implementacijom
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto donošenja ovog amandmana u izolaciji s trenutnim stupanjem na snagu, Ministarstvo evropskih integracija bi predložilo sveobuhvatni paket za zatvaranje Poglavlja 2, koji objedinjuje amandmane o socijalnoj zaštiti s paralelnim mjerama usklađivanja u okviru Uredbe 492/2011, uspostavljanje tijela za jednako postupanje u skladu s članom 4 Direktive 2014/54/EU, te period fazne implementacije od 90 dana. Ovaj paket bi bio predstavljen Evropskoj komisiji kao jedinstveni prijedlog za zatvaranje poglavlja, čime bi se maksimizovao njegov diplomatski značaj i uticaj na mjerila ispunjenosti.
key_changes_mne: Objediniti amandmane o socijalnoj zaštiti s amandmanima koji osiguravaju potpunu transpoziciju Uredbe 492/2011 o pristupu zapošljavanju i uslovima rada
Uključiti odredbe kojima se uspostavlja posebno tijelo za jednako postupanje s nezavisnim mandatom i odgovarajućim kadrovskim kapacitetima, u skladu s članom 4 Direktive 2014/54/EU
Zamijeniti trenutno stupanje na snagu faznom implementacijom u trajanju od 90 dana, kako bi se omogućila institucionalna priprema, obuka osoblja i gotovost IT sistema
Priložiti obaveznu procjenu fiskalnog uticaja i uvesti obavezu godišnjeg izvještavanja Skupštine o broju državljana EU koji ostvaruju pravo na naknade
Uključiti koordinacionu klauzulu kojom se ovaj zakon povezuje s budućim usklađivanjem s Uredbom 883/2004 o koordinaciji sistema socijalne sigurnosti
expected_benefits_mne: Jača pregovaračka pozicija prema Evropskoj komisiji predstavljanjem kompletnog paketa za zatvaranje Poglavlja 2, umjesto fragmentarnog zakonodavstva
Smanjen rizik od implementacionih propusta koji bi mogli biti istaknuti kao nedostaci u narednom izvještaju o napretku
Veća fiskalna transparentnost i parlamentarni nadzor nad budžetskim uticajem
Brži i uvjerljiviji put ka stvarnom zatvaranju Poglavlja 2, što bi predstavljalo prekretnicu u procesu pristupanja Crne Gore
Bolje pozicioniranje za zahtjeve za finansiranje u okviru IPA III, vezane za koherentan plan institucionalnog jačanja
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka. Predložene dodatne mjere već su identifikovane u izvještajima o skriningu Evropske komisije i zahtijevale bi 2–3 mjeseca dodatnog rada na izradi nacrta. Odlaganje implementacije od 90 dana je umjereno i ne bi materijalno usporilo napredak u pristupnom procesu, a istovremeno bi značajno smanjilo rizik od implementacionih teškoća. Politička volja jasno postoji s obzirom na parlamentarnu inicijativu, tako da je glavni uslov koordinacija između Ministarstva rada, Ministarstva finansija i Kancelarije za evropske integracije.

Izmjenama Zakona o socijalnoj i dječijoj zaštiti, kojima se proširuje jednako postupanje na građane EU, EEA i Švajcarske, Crna Gora direktno ispunjava ključni završni benchmark za Poglavlje 2 (Sloboda kretanja radnika) i demonstrira konkretno prenošenje Direktive EU 2014/54/EU. Ministarstvo za evropske integracije smatra ovo modelom načina na koji bi zakonodavno usklađivanje trebalo da teče u svim pregovaračkim poglavljima.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Predložene izmjene predstavljaju izrazito pozitivan razvoj koji direktno cilja završni benchmark za Poglavlje 2. Ključna briga je osiguranje snažnog kapaciteta implementacije i okvira reciprociteta prije nego što zakon stupi na snagu. Samo zakonodavno prenošenje neće zadovoljiti Evropsku komisiju bez dokazanog kapaciteta implementacije, obučenog osoblja i operativnih IT sistema za koordinaciju prekogranične socijalne sigurnosti

Paralelno je potrebno urediti okvire reciprociteta sa državama članicama EU za crnogorske državljane koji rade u inostranstvu, kako bi se osigurala uravnotežena obaveza
Rizik da zakon bude percipiran kao simboličan gest ukoliko mehanizmi provedbe i podnošenja pritužbi ne budu operacionalizovani u kratkom roku

Uspostaviti ili odrediti formalno tijelo za jednako postupanje, kako se zahtijeva članom 4 Direktive 2014/54/EU, s jasnim mandatom, resursima i nezavisnošću za postupanje po pritužbama mobilnih radnika iz EU
Sprovesti procjenu fiskalnog uticaja i predočiti je Parlamentu prije stupanja izmjena na snagu, osiguravajući da su budžetske stavke alocirane u dopunskom budžetu za 2026. godinu, ako je to potrebno

assessments.summary: This decision represents a strategically important and economically sound step toward closing EU accession Chapter 2. By aligning Montenegro's social protection framework with EU Directive 2014/54/EU, the country removes a significant legal barrier to labor mobility, strengthens its credibility as an EU candidate state, and enhances its attractiveness to foreign investors and skilled workers from the EU/EEA/Swiss area. The Ministry of Economy views this as one of the most consequential legislative moves for Montenegro's economic integration trajectory in recent years.
assessments.executive_summary: The Ministry of Economy strongly supports this legislative alignment as essential for EU accession and economic competitiveness. The primary concern is the fiscal sustainability of extending benefits without corresponding revenue from mobile workers, and we recommend pairing this reform with active labor market policies to attract skilled EU workers to sectors where Montenegro faces critical shortages.
assessments.reasoning: From an economic development perspective, this decision directly addresses one of the foundational requirements for Montenegro's integration into the EU single market. Freedom of movement of workers is not merely a legal chapter to be closed; it is a precondition for Montenegro to participate fully in Europe's labor market ecosystem, which has profound implications for productivity, investment, and long-term growth. Montenegro's economy, at roughly 6 billion EUR in GDP, is heavily services-driven and depends on sectors like tourism, real estate, and increasingly IT and business services, all of which benefit enormously from frictionless labor mobility. The current labor market faces a structural paradox: unemployment remains elevated, particularly among youth (over 25%), yet employers in tourism, construction, healthcare, and IT report persistent labor shortages due to skills mismatches and emigration of qualified Montenegrins. Equalizing rights for EU/EEA/Swiss mobile workers makes Montenegro a more viable destination for skilled professionals from the EU who might consider working here, whether in seasonal tourism roles, energy transition projects, or the growing digital economy. Without these protections, Montenegro would remain at a competitive disadvantage relative to other Western Balkan countries advancing their own EU alignment. For foreign direct investment, this is a meaningful signal. International investors, particularly those from EU member states who account for the bulk of FDI into Montenegro, consistently cite legal predictability and EU-compatible regulatory frameworks as key decision factors. A country that discriminates against EU nationals in social protection creates legal uncertainty for companies deploying staff across borders. This amendment removes that friction point. Energy sector investors planning renewable energy projects, industrial operators, and multinational service providers will all view this as evidence of Montenegro's serious commitment to EU standards. Regarding SMEs and entrepreneurship, the decision creates a more level playing field. EU entrepreneurs who establish businesses in Montenegro and employ themselves or bring small teams will now have equal access to social safety nets. This lowers the perceived risk of relocating to Montenegro and could stimulate the kind of cross-border entrepreneurship that has proven beneficial in newer EU member states like Croatia and the Baltic countries. The fiscal implications deserve careful consideration. Montenegro's social protection system is already under strain, and extending benefits to EU mobile workers creates a potential additional cost. However, the actual fiscal impact is likely to be modest in the short term given the relatively small number of EU workers currently resident in Montenegro. Over time, if the reform succeeds in attracting more mobile workers, the tax and social contribution revenues from those workers should offset the costs. The immediate-effect provision is notable. While it demonstrates urgency and political will regarding EU accession, the Ministry notes that implementation readiness of administrative bodies, particularly Centers for Social Work, should have been ensured before enactment. Processing claims from EU nationals requires familiarity with EU coordination regulations (particularly Regulation 883/2004 on social security coordination), and administrative capacity gaps could undermine the law's practical effectiveness.
key_concerns: Fiscal sustainability of extending social and child protection benefits without a clear impact assessment or cost-benefit analysis specific to Montenegro's budget capacity

Administrative readiness of Centers for Social Work and local institutions to process claims from EU/EEA/Swiss nationals under the new framework, including language barriers and unfamiliarity with EU coordination regulations
Risk of asymmetric mobility: Montenegrin workers do not yet enjoy reciprocal rights in EU member states, creating a one-directional obligation until accession is completed
Immediate effect upon publication may not allow sufficient time for training of civil servants and updating of IT systems to handle cross-border social security coordination

Potential public perception risk if citizens view the extension of benefits to foreign nationals as prioritizing EU compliance over domestic social protection needs, especially given ongoing fiscal pressures
recommendations: Conduct a detailed fiscal impact assessment within 60 days of enactment to model the projected costs and revenues associated with EU mobile workers accessing social protection, and publish the results transparently

Launch a targeted capacity-building program for Centers for Social Work and relevant administrative bodies to ensure they can effectively process claims under the new framework, including training on EU Regulation 883/2004

Develop an active labor attraction strategy that leverages this reform to recruit skilled EU workers in sectors with critical shortages, particularly healthcare, IT, renewable energy engineering, and tourism management
Negotiate bilateral arrangements with key EU member states to ensure practical reciprocity for Montenegrin workers abroad, even ahead of formal accession
Pair this reform with enhanced labor market monitoring to track the actual flow of EU mobile workers, their sectoral distribution, and their net fiscal contribution to Montenegro
Use this legislative milestone in investor outreach and FDI promotion materials to demonstrate Montenegro's accelerating EU alignment trajectory

counter_proposal.title: Integrated Labor Mobility and Economic Attraction Package
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Economy would have embedded this legislative reform within a broader economic package that not only equalizes rights but actively leverages the new legal framework to attract high-value EU workers and investors. Rather than a standalone legal amendment, this would be part of a coordinated strategy linking Chapter 2 compliance with labor market activation, FDI promotion, and administrative modernization.
key_changes: Bundle the social protection amendments with a 90-day implementation roadmap including mandatory training for all relevant administrative staff before claims processing begins

Simultaneously launch a Skilled Worker Attraction Program targeting EU professionals in shortage occupations (energy engineers, IT specialists, healthcare workers) with streamlined registration and integration support
Establish a dedicated monitoring unit within the Ministry of Economy to track labor mobility flows, fiscal impacts, and employer satisfaction in real time
Create a public communication strategy explaining to Montenegrin citizens how this reform benefits the domestic economy through job creation, investment, and EU accession progress
expected_benefits: Stronger practical implementation reducing the risk of administrative failures that could embarrass Montenegro before EU evaluators
Measurable increase in skilled EU workers choosing Montenegro, addressing chronic labor shortages in key growth sectors
Better public understanding and support for EU integration reforms, reducing political vulnerability
Enhanced FDI attraction by demonstrating not just legal compliance but operational readiness for EU-standard labor mobility
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility. The legislative component is already being enacted. The additional elements (training program, attraction strategy, monitoring unit, communication plan) require modest additional resources and could be implemented within 3-6 months using existing institutional structures and EU pre-accession assistance funds (IPA III).
counter_proposal.title_mne: Integrisani paket za mobilnost radne snage i ekonomsku privlačnost
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo ekonomije bi ugradilo ovu zakonodavnu reformu u širi ekonomski paket koji ne samo da izjednačava prava, već aktivno koristi novi pravni okvir kako bi privuklo visokokvalifikovane radnike i investitore iz EU. Umjesto samostalne zakonske izmjene, ovo bi bilo dio koordinisane strategije koja povezuje usklađenost s Poglavljem 2 s aktivacijom tržišta rada, promocijom SDI i administrativnom modernizacijom.
key_changes_mne: Objediniti izmjene u oblasti socijalne zaštite s planom implementacije od 90 dana, koji uključuje obaveznu obuku za sve relevantne administrativne službenike prije početka obrade zahtjeva

Istovremeno pokrenuti Program privlačenja kvalifikovanih radnika usmjeren na stručnjake iz EU u deficitarnim zanimanjima (energetski inženjeri, IT stručnjaci, zdravstveni radnici), uz pojednostavljen postupak registracije i podršku pri integraciji
Uspostaviti posebnu jedinicu za praćenje unutar Ministarstva ekonomije radi praćenja tokova radne mobilnosti, fiskalnih uticaja i zadovoljstva poslodavaca u realnom vremenu

Kreirati javnu komunikacijsku strategiju kojom će se građanima Crne Gore objasniti kako ova reforma koristi domaćoj ekonomiji kroz otvaranje radnih mjesta, privlačenje investicija i napredak u procesu pristupanja EU
expected_benefits_mne: Snažnija praktična implementacija koja smanjuje rizik od administrativnih propusta koji bi mogli naštetiti ugledu Crne Gore pred evaluatorima EU
Mjerljivo povećanje broja kvalifikovanih radnika iz EU koji biraju Crnu Goru, čime se rješavaju hronični nedostaci radne snage u ključnim sektorima rasta
