Bolje razumijevanje i podrška javnosti reformama evropskih integracija, što smanjuje političku ranjivost
Pojačano privlačenje stranih direktnih investicija demonstriranjem ne samo pravne usklađenosti, već i operativne spremnosti za mobilnost radne snage po standardima EU
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost. Zakonodavna komponenta već se donosi. Dodatni elementi (program obuke, strategija privlačenja, jedinica za praćenje, komunikacijski plan) zahtijevaju skromna dodatna sredstva i mogli bi biti sprovedeni u roku od 3 do 6 mjeseci korišćenjem postojećih institucionalnih struktura i fondova pretpristupne pomoći EU (IPA III).

assessments.summary_mne: Ova odluka predstavlja strateški važan i ekonomski opravdan korak ka zatvaranju Poglavlja 2 pregovora o pristupanju EU. Usklađivanjem crnogorskog okvira socijalne zaštite sa Direktivom EU 2014/54/EU, zemlja uklanja značajnu pravnu prepreku za mobilnost radne snage, jača kredibilitet kao država kandidat za EU i povećava svoju atraktivnost za strane investitore i kvalifikovane radnike iz prostora EU/EEA/Švajcarske. Ministarstvo ekonomije ovo smatra jednim od najznačajnijih zakonodavnih poteza za ekonomski integracioni put Crne Gore u posljednjih nekoliko godina.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ministarstvo ekonomije snažno podržava ovo zakonodavno usklađivanje kao neophodan korak ka pristupanju EU i ekonomskoj konkurentnosti. Primarni izazov jeste fiskalna održivost proširenja beneficija bez odgovarajućih prihoda od mobilnih radnika, te preporučujemo da se ova reforma poveže s aktivnim politikama tržišta rada u cilju privlačenja kvalifikovanih radnika iz EU u sektore u kojima Crna Gora suočava s kritičnim nedostatkom kadra.
key_concerns_mne: Fiskalna održivost proširenja beneficija socijalne i dječje zaštite bez jasne procjene uticaja ili analize troškova i koristi specifične za budžetske kapacitete Crne Gore

Administrativna spremnost Centara za socijalni rad i lokalnih institucija za obradu zahtjeva državljana EU/EEA/Švajcarske u okviru novog sistema, uključujući jezičke barijere i nepoznavanje EU propisa o koordinaciji
Rizik od asimetrične mobilnosti: crnogorski radnici još uvijek ne uživaju recipročna prava u državama članicama EU, što stvara jednosmjernu obavezu sve do završetka pristupnog procesa

Neposredno stupanje na snagu po objavljivanju možda neće ostaviti dovoljno vremena za obuku državnih službenika i ažuriranje IT sistema za upravljanje prekograničnom koordinacijom socijalne sigurnosti

Potencijalni rizik po javnu percepciju ukoliko građani doživljaju proširenje beneficija na strane državljane kao davanje prioriteta usklađivanju s EU nauštrb domaćih potreba socijalne zaštite, posebno u kontekstu tekućih fiskalnih pritisaka
recommendations_mne: Sprovesti detaljnu procjenu fiskalnog uticaja u roku od 60 dana od usvajanja, kako bi se modelirali projektovani troškovi i prihodi vezani za pristup socijalnoj zaštiti od strane mobilnih radnika iz EU, te transparentno objaviti rezultate

Pokrenuti ciljani program izgradnje kapaciteta za Centre za socijalni rad i nadležna administrativna tijela kako bi se osigurala efikasna obrada zahtjeva u okviru novog sistema, uključujući obuku o Uredbi EU 883/2004

Razviti aktivnu strategiju privlačenja radne snage kojom se ova reforma koristi za regrutovanje kvalifikovanih radnika iz EU u sektorima sa kritičnim nedostatkom kadra, posebno u zdravstvu, IT-u, inženjeringu obnovljive energije i upravljanju turizmom
Pregovarati o bilateralnim aranžmanima s ključnim državama članicama EU kako bi se osigurala praktična recipročnost za crnogorske radnike u inostranstvu, i to prije formalnog pristupanja
Ovu reformu pratiti pojačanim monitoringom tržišta rada radi praćenja stvarnog kretanja mobilnih radnika iz EU, njihove sektorske distribucije i neto fiskalnog doprinosa Crnoj Gori
Koristiti ovaj zakonodavni iskorak u aktivnostima privlačenja investitora i promociji SDI kako bi se demonstrirao ubrzani put crnogorskog usklađivanja s EU

assessments.summary: Equalizing social protection rights for EU, EEA, and Swiss workers represents a meaningful positive step for Montenegro's tourism sector, which depends heavily on seasonal labour mobility and EU accession credibility. By aligning with Directive 2014/54/EU and advancing Chapter 2 closure, this decision strengthens Montenegro's institutional readiness for EU membership, a factor that directly enhances investor confidence in tourism infrastructure and signals regulatory maturity to European tour operators, cruise lines, and hospitality chains considering Montenegrin market entry.
assessments.executive_summary: This decision is positive for tourism because it facilitates the seasonal labour mobility Montenegro desperately needs and accelerates EU accession, which is the single most important long-term driver of tourism sector credibility. The Ministry's primary concern is that social protection equalization without a parallel strategy for seasonal workforce integration could increase fiscal exposure without capturing the full benefits. We recommend coupling this legislative change with a targeted seasonal worker attraction programme for the hospitality sector.
assessments.reasoning:
Montenegro's tourism sector contributes roughly 25-40 percent of GDP depending on measurement methodology, and is structurally dependent on seasonal labour concentrated between May and October. The coastal municipalities of Budva, Kotor, Herceg Novi, Tivat, and Ulcinj experience acute labour shortages every season, with hotels, restaurants, and tour operators routinely unable to fill positions. This problem has worsened as Montenegrin workers emigrate to the EU and regional competitors like Croatia (already an EU member) and Albania (candidate with growing tourism) compete for the same mobile workforce.

Equalizing social protection rights for EU and EEA workers directly addresses one of the structural barriers to attracting qualified seasonal workers from EU member states. Currently, an experienced hospitality professional from Slovenia, Croatia, or Slovakia considering seasonal work in Montenegro faces uncertainty about social protection coverage, creating a disincentive compared to working in an EU member state where these rights are guaranteed. Removing this barrier, even if it primarily affects a small number of workers in the near term, sends an important signal and builds the legal infrastructure Montenegro will need when accession accelerates labour mobility.

From the EU accession perspective, closing Chapter 2 is strategically important for tourism. Montenegro's brand positioning increasingly depends on its EU candidate status. High-value tourists from Western Europe, Scandinavian adventure travellers interested in Durmitor and Prokletije, and cultural heritage visitors to Kotor's UNESCO Old Town all factor institutional stability and European integration into their destination choices. Every closed chapter reinforces the narrative that Montenegro is a stable, European-standard destination rather than a risky post-Yugoslav frontier.

The cruise ship sector in Kotor Bay also benefits indirectly. Major cruise lines like MSC, Costa, and Royal Caribbean evaluate port destinations partly on regulatory alignment with EU standards. A Montenegro that is visibly progressing through accession chapters is a more attractive port call than one that appears stalled.

However, there are legitimate concerns. The fiscal impact of extending full social and child protection benefits to EU mobile workers needs careful modelling. If Montenegro attracts significant numbers of seasonal workers who bring families and access child protection benefits, the cost could fall disproportionately on coastal municipalities already strained by seasonal population surges. Budva's permanent population of approximately 20,000 swells to over 100,000 in summer, and municipal services are already under pressure.

Additionally, the decision addresses the legal framework but does not tackle the operational reality of seasonal employment in Montenegrin tourism. Many seasonal workers, both domestic and foreign, operate in grey or informal employment arrangements. Social protection equalization has limited practical value if enforcement of labour standards remains weak. The Ministry of Tourism has long advocated for stronger labour inspection capacity in coastal zones during the tourist season.

Finally, while this is a necessary legislative alignment, it is not sufficient on its own to solve tourism labour shortages. Montenegro needs a proactive seasonal worker attraction strategy, including simplified work permit processes, multilingual recruitment platforms, and partnerships with EU hospitality training institutions, to actually convert this legal change into workforce gains.
key_concerns: Fiscal exposure from extending social and child protection benefits without clear cost modelling, particularly for coastal municipalities already under seasonal population pressure
Limited practical impact if grey economy and informal seasonal employment remain unaddressed by labour inspections
Risk that legislative alignment creates rights on paper without operational infrastructure to administer claims from mobile EU workers efficiently
No accompanying workforce attraction strategy to convert legal equalization into actual seasonal labour supply gains for tourism
Potential asymmetry where Montenegro extends benefits to EU workers while Montenegrin seasonal workers abroad do not yet enjoy full reciprocal rights until accession is complete
recommendations: Develop a fiscal impact assessment specific to tourism-heavy coastal municipalities estimating the cost of social and child protection claims from EU mobile workers under various seasonal employment scenarios

Launch a parallel Seasonal Tourism Workforce Programme targeting EU hospitality professionals with simplified administrative procedures, multilingual support, and partnerships with hotel and restaurant associations

Strengthen labour inspection capacity in Budva, Kotor, Tivat, and Herceg Novi during May-October to ensure new social protection rights are practically enforceable and not undermined by informal employment
Coordinate with the Ministry of Labour to create a digital portal for EU mobile workers to register, access benefits information, and file claims, reducing administrative friction
Use Chapter 2 progress in Montenegro's international tourism marketing as evidence of European integration and destination reliability

counter_proposal.title: Integrated Seasonal Labour Mobility and Social Protection Framework for Tourism
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Tourism would support the legislative equalization but embed it within a broader seasonal labour mobility strategy. Rather than treating social protection alignment as a standalone legal compliance exercise, we would pair it with a targeted seasonal worker attraction programme, enhanced labour inspection enforcement in tourism zones, and a digital registration system for mobile workers. This ensures the legal change translates into tangible workforce benefits for the tourism sector while managing fiscal risks.
key_changes: Attach a fiscal impact annex to the amendments estimating costs for tourism municipalities and establishing a cost-sharing mechanism between central and local government
Create a Tourism Seasonal Worker Fast-Track scheme offering streamlined registration and benefits access for EU nationals employed in licensed tourism establishments
Mandate that the law's implementation be accompanied by a 50 percent increase in labour inspection staff in coastal municipalities during peak season
Establish bilateral seasonal worker agreements with key EU source countries such as Slovenia, Slovakia, and Bulgaria targeting hospitality sector professionals
expected_benefits: Reduction in seasonal labour shortages in coastal tourism by attracting qualified EU hospitality workers with guaranteed social protection
Improved service quality in hotels and restaurants through access to a broader and better-trained seasonal workforce
Stronger EU accession narrative that can be leveraged in tourism destination marketing
Reduced informal employment in tourism through better enforcement and clearer benefits framework
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility for the legislative component, which is already in motion. The accompanying seasonal worker programme and enhanced labour inspections would require moderate additional budget allocation, estimated at 1-2 million euros annually, which could be partially funded through EU IPA pre-accession funds designated for labour market reforms. Bilateral agreements with Slovenia and Slovakia could build on existing diplomatic relationships and be operational within 12-18 months.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Integrisani okvir sezonske radne mobilnosti i socijalne zaštite za turizam
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo turizma podržalo bi zakonodavno izjednačavanje, ali bi ga ugradilo u širu strategiju sezonske radne mobilnosti. Umjesto da se usklađivanje socijalne zaštite tretira kao zasebna vježba zakonske usklađenosti, objedinili bismo ga s ciljanim programom privlačenja sezonskih radnika, pojačanom kontrolom rada u turističkim zonama i digitalnim sistemom registracije mobilnih radnika. Na taj način zakonska promjena se prevodi u konkretne koristi za radnu snagu u turističkom sektoru, uz istovremeno upravljanje fiskalnim rizicima.
key_changes_mne: Priložiti fiskalni aneks uz izmjene zakona kojim se procjenjuju troškovi za turističke opštine i uspostavlja mehanizam podjele troškova između centralnih i lokalnih organa vlasti

Uspostaviti shemu ubrzanog postupka za sezonske radnike u turizmu, koja nudi pojednostavljen postupak registracije i pristup beneficijama za državljane EU zaposlene u licenciranim turističkim objektima
Obavezati da primjena zakona bude praćena povećanjem broja inspektora rada za 50 posto u primorskim opštinama tokom sezone
Zaključiti bilateralne sporazume o sezonskim radnicima s ključnim izvornim zemljama EU, kao što su Slovenija, Slovačka i Bugarska, s fokusom na stručnjake u sektoru ugostiteljstva
expected_benefits_mne: Smanjenje sezonskih nedostataka radne snage u primorskom turizmu privlačenjem kvalifikovanih ugostiteljskih radnika iz EU s garantovanom socijalnom zaštitom
Poboljšan kvalitet usluga u hotelima i restoranima zahvaljujući pristupu široj i bolje obučenoj sezonskoj radnoj snazi
Snažniji narativ o pristupanju EU koji se može iskoristiti u marketingu turističke destinacije
Smanjenje sive ekonomije u turizmu kroz bolju primjenu propisa i jasniji okvir beneficija
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost kada je riječ o zakonodavnoj komponenti, koja je već u toku. Prateći program za sezonske radnike i pojačane inspekcije rada zahtijevali bi umjerena dodatna budžetska sredstva, procijenjena na 1–2 miliona eura godišnje, koja bi se djelimično mogla finansirati iz fondova EU IPA za predpristupnu pomoć namijenjenih reformama tržišta rada. Bilateralni sporazumi sa Slovenijom i Slovačkom mogli bi se nadovezati na postojeće diplomatske odnose i biti operativni u roku od 12–18 mjeseci.

assessments.summary_mne: Izjednačavanje prava na socijalnu zaštitu za radnike iz EU, EEP-a i Švajcarske predstavlja značajan pozitivan korak za crnogorski turistički sektor, koji u velikoj mjeri zavisi od sezonske mobilnosti radne snage i kredibiliteta u procesu pristupanja EU. Usklađivanjem sa Direktivom 2014/54/EU i napredovanjem ka zatvaranju Poglavlja 2, ova odluka jača institucionalnu spremnost Crne Gore za članstvo u EU – faktor koji direktno povećava povjerenje investitora u turističku infrastrukturu i signalizira regulatornu zrelost evropskim turoperatorima, kruzerskim kompanijama i hotelskim lancima koji razmatraju ulazak na crnogorsko tržište.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ova odluka pozitivno djeluje na turizam jer olakšava sezonsku mobilnost radne snage koja je Crnoj Gori prijeko potrebna i ubrzava pristupanje EU, što predstavlja najvažniji dugoročni pokretač kredibiliteta turističkog sektora. Primarna zabrinutost Ministarstva ogleda se u tome što izjednačavanje socijalne zaštite bez paralelne strategije za integraciju sezonske radne snage može povećati fiskalnu izloženost, a da se pritom ne iskoriste sve prednosti. Preporučujemo da se ova zakonodavna promjena upari s ciljanim programom privlačenja sezonskih radnika za ugostiteljski sektor.
key_concerns_mne: Fiskalna izloženost usljed proširenja prava na socijalnu zaštitu i zaštitu djece bez jasnog modeliranja troškova, posebno za primorske opštine koje su već pod pritiskom sezonskog porasta stanovništva
Ograničen praktični učinak ukoliko siva ekonomija i neformalno sezonsko zapošljavanje ostanu van dometa inspekcije rada
Rizik da zakonodavno usklađivanje stvara prava na papiru bez operativne infrastrukture za efikasno rješavanje zahtjeva mobilnih radnika iz EU
Nedostatak prateće strategije za privlačenje radne snage koja bi pravno izjednačavanje pretvorila u stvarno povećanje ponude sezonske radne snage u turizmu

Potencijalna asimetrija u kojoj Crna Gora proširuje beneficije na radnike iz EU, dok crnogorski sezonski radnici u inostranstvu još uvijek ne uživaju potpunu reciprocitet prava sve do završetka procesa pristupanja
recommendations_mne: Izraditi procjenu fiskalnog uticaja prilagođenu primorskim opštinama s intenzivnim turizmom, uz procjenu troškova zahtjeva za socijalnu zaštitu i zaštitu djece od strane mobilnih radnika iz EU u različitim scenarijima sezonskog zapošljavanja

Pokrenuti paralelni Program sezonske turističke radne snage usmjeren na ugostiteljske stručnjake iz EU, s pojednostavljenim administrativnim postupcima, višejezičnom podrškom i partnerstvima s hotelskim i restoranskim udruženjima

Ojačati kapacitete inspekcije rada u Budvi, Kotoru, Tivtu i Herceg Novom u periodu od maja do oktobra, kako bi se osiguralo da nova prava na socijalnu zaštitu budu praktično primjenjiva i da ih neformalno zapošljavanje ne potkopa

Koordinisati se s Ministarstvom rada na uspostavljanju digitalnog portala za mobilne radnike iz EU, putem kojeg bi mogli da se registruju, pristupe informacijama o beneficijama i podnesu zahtjeve, čime bi se smanjilo administrativno opterećenje
Koristiti napredak u okviru Poglavlja 2 u međunarodnom turističkom marketingu Crne Gore kao dokaz evropskih integracija i pouzdanosti destinacije

assessments.summary: This legislative amendment, while primarily targeting social and child protection under Chapter 2, carries meaningful indirect implications for the education sector. By equalizing rights for EU, EEA, and Swiss mobile workers, Montenegro creates a more attractive environment for incoming skilled professionals, including educators and researchers, while simultaneously establishing the reciprocal legal framework that will eventually allow Montenegrin workers equal treatment abroad. The alignment with Directive 2014/54/EU is a necessary and welcome step toward EU accession, though it raises practical questions about how education-adjacent benefits (school meals, textbooks, student welfare) will be extended and funded.
assessments.executive_summary: The Ministry of Education views this as a positive step toward EU accession that will facilitate academic mobility and attract foreign education professionals to Montenegro. The primary concern is ensuring that child protection benefits linked to education (free textbooks, school meals, scholarships) are clearly covered and adequately funded. We recommend parallel amendments to education-specific legislation to fully capture the benefits of this alignment.
assessments.reasoning:
The decision to equalize social and child protection rights for EU, EEA, and Swiss nationals directly supports Montenegro's EU accession process under Chapter 2, which is intrinsically linked to the free movement framework that underpins key EU education programs. From the education perspective, several dimensions deserve attention.

First, regarding student welfare and equity: Montenegrin social and child protection law provides benefits that intersect significantly with education, including allowances for children, subsidies for school supplies, free textbooks under the Law on Textbooks, and school meal programs. Extending these to children of EU mobile workers residing in Montenegro is both a legal obligation under the directive and an ethical imperative for educational equity. However, the current amendment text reportedly focuses on the Law on Social and Child Protection, and it is unclear whether all education-adjacent entitlements are fully captured or whether parallel amendments to the General Law on Education or the Law on Higher Education will follow.

Second, regarding higher education and research: equalizing treatment for EU nationals strengthens Montenegro's position as a destination for visiting researchers, lecturers, and postdoctoral fellows. The University of Montenegro and private institutions such as UDG and Mediteran have struggled to attract international academic talent. If EU citizens working in Montenegro can access the same social safety net, this removes one barrier to recruitment. This is particularly relevant given Montenegro's participation in Horizon Europe and Erasmus+ where researcher mobility is a priority.

Third, regarding teacher training and workforce: Montenegro faces a structural shortage of qualified teachers in STEM subjects, foreign languages, and vocational education. The equalization of rights makes it marginally easier to recruit EU-national teachers, though the more significant barriers remain salary levels (averaging around 600-750 EUR monthly for teachers) and recognition of foreign qualifications. The decision is a necessary but insufficient condition for addressing teacher shortages through international recruitment.

Fourth, on brain drain mitigation: this is a double-edged issue. While the amendment makes Montenegro more attractive to incoming EU workers, the reciprocal framework being built also facilitates Montenegrin citizens accessing social protection abroad. Given that Montenegro already loses an estimated 2,000-3,000 young people annually to emigration, many of them university-educated, the concern is that full Chapter 2 alignment may accelerate outward mobility of educated Montenegrins toward EU labor markets where wages are five to ten times higher. This is a structural risk that the education system must prepare for, not by opposing the amendment, but by strengthening retention incentives domestically.

Fifth, regarding EU education standards alignment: closing Chapter 2 sends a strong signal of progress in accession negotiations, which benefits the education sector indirectly by maintaining Montenegro's credibility in EU program participation. Full alignment with Directive 2014/54/EU also creates legal coherence with the Bologna Process framework and mutual recognition agreements, which is important for higher education.

The immediate fiscal impact on the education budget is likely modest, as the number of EU mobile workers with school-age children in Montenegro is currently small. However, as accession progresses and mobility increases, the Ministry must be prepared to scale services accordingly.
key_concerns: The amendment to the Law on Social and Child Protection may not fully cover education-specific entitlements such as free textbooks, school meals, scholarship eligibility, and VET stipends, which are governed by separate education legislation.
Reciprocal free movement rights may accelerate brain drain of qualified Montenegrin teachers, STEM graduates, and medical education professionals toward higher-wage EU labor markets.

There is no accompanying impact assessment on how many additional children of EU mobile workers may enter the Montenegrin school system and what linguistic or curricular accommodations they may require.
Teacher salary competitiveness remains the binding constraint on attracting EU-national educators, and this amendment alone does not address that gap.
The fiscal sustainability of extending child protection benefits linked to education has not been publicly evaluated, even if current numbers are small.
recommendations: Conduct a parallel legal review of the General Law on Education, the Law on Higher Education, and the Law on Textbooks to identify any provisions that discriminate based on nationality and prepare corresponding amendments for full Chapter 2 compliance.
Develop a protocol for integrating children of EU mobile workers into Montenegrin schools, including language support in Montenegrin and provisions for multilingual education where numbers warrant.

Use this legislative moment to negotiate with the EU for expanded Erasmus+ and Horizon Europe funding specifically targeting incoming academic mobility to Montenegro, leveraging the improved legal framework.

Establish a monitoring mechanism within the Ministry to track the impact of Chapter 2 alignment on both inward mobility of education professionals and outward mobility (brain drain) of Montenegrin graduates and teachers.
Coordinate with the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare to ensure that the implementing regulations clearly define which education-related benefits fall under the scope of the amended law.

counter_proposal.title: Comprehensive Education Mobility Alignment Package
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than relying solely on amendments to the Law on Social and Child Protection, the Ministry of Education would propose a parallel legislative package that explicitly extends equal treatment to education-specific entitlements, creates integration support for children of mobile workers, and pairs the opening of the labor market with targeted retention measures for Montenegrin education professionals.
key_changes: Amend Articles of the General Law on Education and the Law on Higher Education to explicitly guarantee non-discrimination for EU, EEA, and Swiss nationals in access to public education, scholarships, and student welfare services.
Establish an Education Integration Support Unit within the Bureau for Education Services to assist schools receiving children of EU mobile workers with language instruction and curricular adaptation.

Introduce a Teacher Retention Incentive Scheme offering salary supplements, housing assistance, and professional development grants for qualified Montenegrin teachers who commit to five-year service in underserved areas, counterbalancing potential outward mobility.
Fast-track mutual recognition of teaching qualifications with EU member states, enabling two-way mobility that benefits Montenegro's schools.
Request that the EU Delegation to Montenegro allocate IPA III education sector funds specifically for the administrative costs of implementing Chapter 2 in the education domain.
expected_benefits: Full legal certainty for EU nationals accessing Montenegrin education services, removing any ambiguity that could delay Chapter 2 closure.
Smoother integration of children of mobile workers, preventing ad hoc responses that could strain individual schools.
Reduced risk of teacher brain drain through targeted domestic retention measures.
Enhanced credibility with EU screening bodies by demonstrating that Montenegro has addressed education dimensions of free movement proactively.
Attraction of EU-national teachers and researchers to fill critical shortage areas in STEM and vocational education.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility. The legislative amendments are straightforward and could be drafted within two to three months. The Teacher Retention Incentive Scheme would require budget allocation of approximately 1.5 to 2 million EUR annually, which could be partially covered through IPA III reallocation. The Education Integration Support Unit could initially operate with three to five staff within existing Bureau structures. Political will is the main variable, but the accession momentum provides strong incentive.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Sveobuhvatni paket za usklađivanje obrazovne mobilnosti
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto da se oslanja isključivo na izmjene Zakona o socijalnoj i dječjoj zaštiti, Ministarstvo prosvjete predložilo bi paralelni zakonodavni paket koji izričito proširuje jednako postupanje na prava specifična za oblast obrazovanja, stvara podršku za integraciju djece mobilnih radnika i uparuje otvaranje tržišta rada s ciljanim mjerama zadržavanja crnogorskih prosvjetnih radnika.
key_changes_mne: Izmijeniti članove Opšteg zakona o obrazovanju i Zakona o visokom obrazovanju kako bi se izričito garantovalo nediskriminatorno postupanje prema državljanima EU, EEP-a i Švajcarske u pogledu pristupa javnom obrazovanju, stipendijama i studentskim socijalnim uslugama.

Osnovati Jedinicu za podršku integraciji u obrazovanju unutar Zavoda za obrazovne usluge, radi pružanja pomoći školama koje primaju djecu mobilnih radnika iz EU u oblasti nastave jezika i prilagođavanja nastavnog plana.

Uvesti Program podsticaja za zadržavanje nastavnog kadra koji nudi dodatke na platu, pomoć u stambenoj sferi i grantove za stručno usavršavanje kvalifikovanim crnogorskim nastavnicima koji se obavežu na petogodišnji rad u nedovoljno razvijenim područjima, čime se uravnotežuje potencijalna odlazna mobilnost.
Ubrzati uzajamno priznavanje nastavničkih kvalifikacija s državama članicama EU, omogućavajući dvosmjernu mobilnost koja donosi korist crnogorskim školama.
Zatražiti od Delegacije EU u Crnoj Gori da sredstva IPA III namijenjena sektoru obrazovanja rasporedi konkretno za administrativne troškove primjene Poglavlja 2 u oblasti obrazovanja.
expected_benefits_mne: Potpuna pravna sigurnost za državljane EU koji pristupaju crnogorskim obrazovnim uslugama, čime se otklanja svaka nejasnoća koja bi mogla odložiti zatvaranje Poglavlja 2.
Lakša integracija djece mobilnih radnika, uz sprječavanje ad hoc rješenja koja bi mogla opteretiti pojedine škole.
Smanjen rizik od odljeva nastavničkog kadra zahvaljujući ciljanim domaćim mjerama zadržavanja.
Jači kredibilitet pred tijelima EU za skrining, demonstriranjem da je Crna Gora proaktivno riješila pitanja obrazovne dimenzije slobodnog kretanja.
Privlačenje nastavnika i istraživača iz zemalja EU radi popunjavanja kritičnih nedostataka u oblasti STEM obrazovanja i stručnog osposobljavanja.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost. Zakonodavne izmjene su jednostavne i mogle bi biti izrađene u roku od dva do tri mjeseca. Program podsticaja za zadržavanje nastavnog kadra zahtijevao bi godišnju budžetsku alokaciju od oko 1,5 do 2 miliona EUR, koja bi se djelimično mogla pokriti preraspodjelom sredstava IPA III. Jedinica za podršku integraciji u obrazovanju mogla bi u početku funkcionisati s tri do pet zaposlenih unutar postojećih struktura Zavoda. Politička volja je ključna varijabla, ali zamah pristupnog procesa pruža snažan podsticaj.

assessments.summary_mne: Ova zakonodavna izmjena, iako se prvenstveno odnosi na socijalnu zaštitu i zaštitu djece u okviru Poglavlja 2, ima značajne posredne implikacije za sektor obrazovanja. Izjednačavanjem prava mobilnih radnika iz EU, EEP-a i Švajcarske, Crna Gora stvara atraktivnije okruženje za dolazak stručnjaka, uključujući nastavnike i istraživače, istovremeno uspostavljajući recipročni pravni okvir koji će u konačnici omogućiti crnogorskim radnicima ravnopravan tretman u inostranstvu. Usklađivanje sa Direktivom 2014/54/EU predstavlja neophodan i dobrodošao korak ka pristupanju EU, mada otvara praktična pitanja o tome kako će se beneficije vezane za obrazovanje (školska ishrana, udžbenici, studentski standard) proširiti i finansirati.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ministarstvo prosvjete ovaj korak doživljava kao pozitivan napredak ka pristupanju EU, koji će olakšati akademsku mobilnost i privući strane obrazovne stručnjake u Crnu Goru. Primarna briga jeste osigurati da beneficije dječje zaštite vezane za obrazovanje (besplatni udžbenici, školska ishrana, stipendije) budu jasno obuhvaćene i adekvatno finansirane. Preporučujemo paralelne izmjene zakonodavstva specifičnog za obrazovanje kako bi se u potpunosti iskoristile prednosti ovog usklađivanja.
key_concerns_mne: Izmjena Zakona o socijalnoj i dječjoj zaštiti možda neće u potpunosti obuhvatiti prava specifična za obrazovanje, kao što su besplatni udžbenici, školska ishrana, pravo na stipendije i naknade u okviru stručnog obrazovanja, koja su regulisana posebnim zakonodavstvom iz oblasti obrazovanja.

Recipročna prava slobodnog kretanja mogu ubrzati odliv mozgova kvalifikovanih crnogorskih nastavnika, diplomiranih stručnjaka iz oblasti STEM-a i profesionalaca u medicinskom obrazovanju prema tržištima rada u EU s višim platama.
Ne postoji prateća procjena uticaja o tome koliko bi dodatne djece mobilnih radnika iz EU moglo ući u crnogorski školski sistem i kakve bi jezičke ili kurikularne prilagodbe mogle biti potrebne.
Konkurentnost nastavničkih plata ostaje ključno ograničenje u privlačenju nastavnika koji su državljani EU, a ova izmjena sama po sebi ne rješava taj jaz.
Fiskalna održivost proširenja beneficija dječje zaštite vezanih za obrazovanje nije javno ocijenjena, čak i ako su trenutni brojevi mali.
recommendations_mne: Sprovesti paralelnu pravnu analizu Opšteg zakona o obrazovanju, Zakona o visokom obrazovanju i Zakona o udžbenicima kako bi se identifikovale odredbe koje diskriminišu na osnovu državljanstva, te pripremiti odgovarajuće izmjene radi potpune usklađenosti sa Poglavljem 2.

Razviti protokol za uključivanje djece mobilnih radnika iz EU u crnogorske škole, uključujući podršku u učenju crnogorskog jezika i mjere za višejezično obrazovanje tamo gdje to broj učenika opravdava.

Iskoristiti ovaj zakonodavni trenutak za pregovaranje s EU o proširenom finansiranju u okviru programa Erasmus+ i Horizont Evropa, s posebnim fokusom na dolaznu akademsku mobilnost u Crnu Goru, koristeći poboljšani pravni okvir kao polugu.

Uspostaviti mehanizam praćenja u okviru Ministarstva kako bi se mjerio uticaj usklađivanja sa Poglavljem 2, kako na dolaznu mobilnost obrazovnih stručnjaka, tako i na odlaznu mobilnost (odliv mozgova) crnogorskih diplomiranih studenata i nastavnika.
Koordinisati sa Ministarstvom rada i socijalnog staranja kako bi se osiguralo da provedbeni propisi jasno definišu koje beneficije vezane za obrazovanje potpadaju pod djelokrug izmijenjenog zakona.

assessments.summary: The proposed amendments to the Law on Social and Child Protection represent a necessary and broadly welcome step toward EU accession by aligning Montenegro with Directive 2014/54/EU and the requirements of Chapter 2 (Freedom of Movement of Workers). Extending equal social and child protection rights to EU, EEA, and Swiss citizens is both a legal obligation on the accession path and a signal of institutional maturity. However, the Ministry has significant concerns about the absence of fiscal impact analysis, the readiness of Centres for Social Work to administer new caseloads, the lack of reciprocity safeguards during the pre-accession period, and the notably absent coordination with pension and disability insurance frameworks.
assessments.executive_summary: This is a fundamentally sound legislative initiative required for EU accession, but it is being advanced too hastily and too narrowly. The Ministry's top concern is that no fiscal impact assessment or institutional capacity plan has accompanied the amendments, and the failure to simultaneously address pension portability and labour market coordination risks creating an incomplete and operationally strained framework. We recommend a phased implementation with accompanying capacity-building measures.
assessments.reasoning:
From a legal alignment perspective, these amendments are overdue. EU Directive 2014/54/EU requires that mobile EU workers enjoy equal treatment in social advantages, including social protection and child benefits, without discrimination on the basis of nationality. Chapter 2 benchmarks have explicitly called on Montenegro to adopt such provisions, and the European Commission's annual progress reports have repeatedly flagged this gap. The parliamentary initiative is therefore correct in its objective and necessary for credible accession negotiations.

However, the Ministry identifies several areas of concern. First, the amendments appear to have been submitted without a Regulatory Impact Assessment (RIA), which is required under Montenegrin law for significant legislative changes. The fiscal implications of extending social and child protection benefits -- including material support (materijalno obezbjedjenje), child allowances (djecji dodatak), one-time assistance (jednokratna pomoc), and personal disability benefits -- to a new category of beneficiaries have not been publicly quantified. While the current number of EU citizens resident and working in Montenegro is relatively small, accession itself and the signal effect of these amendments could increase inflows. Without projections, the budget of the Ministry and the social protection system risks being caught unprepared.

Second, the Centres for Social Work (Centri za socijalni rad), which are the frontline institutions for administering social and child protection, are already under significant strain. Many centres, particularly outside Podgorica, face staffing shortages, high caseloads, and inadequate IT infrastructure. Adding a new beneficiary category with potentially different documentation requirements, language barriers, and cross-border verification needs without first investing in capacity is a recipe for implementation failure and discriminatory delays in practice even where the law guarantees equal treatment.

Third, the amendments address social and child protection but appear silent on pension and disability insurance coordination. Regulation (EC) No 883/2004 on the coordination of social security systems is the cornerstone of Chapter 2 compliance and covers old-age pensions, disability benefits, sickness benefits, and unemployment benefits. Aligning only one pillar of social protection while leaving pension portability and disability insurance coordination unaddressed creates an asymmetric and incomplete framework. The Fond PIO must be brought into alignment simultaneously, or Montenegro risks a partial compliance finding from the European Commission.

Fourth, there is a question of reciprocity during the pre-accession period. Until Montenegro formally joins the EU, Montenegrin workers in EU member states benefit from bilateral agreements of varying scope and quality, not from automatic equal treatment. Extending full equal treatment unilaterally before accession, without at minimum a transitional framework or a linkage to bilateral social security agreements, may create a one-sided obligation that the Ministry considers politically and fiscally imprudent.

Fifth, the immediate entry into force upon publication in the Official Gazette leaves no transition period for institutional adaptation, staff training, IT system updates, or public information campaigns. Best practice in EU member states and in comparable Western Balkan reform processes (for example, Serbia's phased approach to social security coordination) suggests a minimum six-month vacatio legis for changes of this nature.

Finally, the Ministry notes that the Social Council (Socijalni savjet) and relevant trade unions and employers associations do not appear to have been consulted on these amendments. Social dialogue is a fundamental principle of EU social policy and a requirement under ILO Convention No. 144 on Tripartite Consultation. Bypassing the Social Council on a matter that directly affects the labour market and social protection system undermines both the spirit of EU accession and Montenegro's own institutional framework for social dialogue.
key_concerns: No Regulatory Impact Assessment or fiscal analysis has been published to quantify the budgetary cost of extending benefits to a new category of beneficiaries.
Centres for Social Work lack the staffing, IT infrastructure, and multilingual capacity to process claims from EU and EEA nationals without significant preparatory investment.
Pension and disability insurance coordination under Regulation (EC) No 883/2004 is not addressed, creating an incomplete and asymmetric compliance framework for Chapter 2.
Immediate entry into force allows no transition period for institutional preparation, staff training, or IT system adaptation.
The Social Council and social partners were apparently not consulted, violating principles of social dialogue central to both EU accession and ILO conventions ratified by Montenegro.
Unilateral extension of full equal treatment before accession, without reciprocity safeguards or linkage to bilateral social security agreements, creates a one-sided fiscal obligation.
recommendations: Conduct and publish a full Regulatory Impact Assessment including fiscal projections for the next five years, covering all benefit categories under the Law on Social and Child Protection.

Introduce a vacatio legis of at least six months to allow Centres for Social Work to prepare operationally, including staff training on cross-border case management and IT system upgrades for verifying entitlements of foreign nationals.
Submit parallel amendments to the Law on Pension and Disability Insurance to begin aligning the Fond PIO with Regulation (EC) No 883/2004, ensuring a comprehensive approach to Chapter 2 compliance.
Refer the amendments to the Social Council for formal consultation with trade unions and employers associations before parliamentary adoption.

Develop a transitional framework that links the scope of benefits available to EU nationals to the existence of bilateral or multilateral social security agreements ensuring reciprocal treatment for Montenegrin workers abroad.

Allocate dedicated budget to the Employment Bureau (Zavod za zaposljavnje) and Centres for Social Work for multilingual service provision and a public information campaign targeting both EU mobile workers and Montenegrin institutions.

counter_proposal.title: Phased Equal Treatment Implementation with Institutional Readiness Plan
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare would support the same legislative objective but through a phased approach. Rather than immediate and isolated amendments to the Law on Social and Child Protection, we would propose a comprehensive Social Security Coordination Reform Package that simultaneously addresses social protection, pension portability, disability insurance, and unemployment benefits. Implementation would follow a six-month preparatory phase during which Centres for Social Work and the Fond PIO would receive targeted capacity-building support. The Social Council would be formally consulted, and a Regulatory Impact Assessment would be completed before parliamentary vote.
key_changes: Bundle amendments to the Law on Social and Child Protection with parallel amendments to the Law on Pension and Disability Insurance and the Law on Employment and Insurance Against Unemployment to create a comprehensive Chapter 2 compliance package.
Introduce a six-month vacatio legis with a mandatory institutional readiness certification by the Ministry before the provisions take effect.
Mandate a Regulatory Impact Assessment with five-year fiscal projections as a precondition for parliamentary debate.
Require formal Social Council consultation and publish the social partners' opinions alongside the legislative text.
Establish a dedicated cross-border social security coordination unit within the Ministry to handle complex cases involving EU mobile workers, reducing the burden on local Centres for Social Work.
Link the extension of certain non-contributory benefits to the existence of reciprocal bilateral agreements during the pre-accession period.
expected_benefits: Full and genuine Chapter 2 compliance rather than partial alignment that risks a negative European Commission assessment on coordination of social security systems.
Operationally prepared institutions that can deliver equal treatment in practice, not just on paper, preventing de facto discrimination through administrative delays.
Fiscally responsible implementation with transparent cost projections enabling the Ministry of Finance to plan budget allocations.
Strengthened social dialogue consistent with EU accession requirements under Chapter 19 (Social Policy and Employment).
Protection of Montenegrin workers' interests abroad through reciprocity linkages during the pre-accession transition.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. The legislative content would remain substantially the same; the key change is sequencing, institutional preparation, and comprehensiveness. A six-month delay is modest and would not jeopardize the Chapter 2 negotiating timeline, which operates on multi-year horizons. The European Commission has consistently valued quality of transposition over speed, and a comprehensive package would likely be received more favourably than a piecemeal amendment.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Postupna implementacija jednakog tretmana sa planom institucionalne spremnosti
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo rada i socijalnog staranja podržalo bi isti zakonodavni cilj, ali putem postupnog pristupa. Umjesto trenutnih i izolovanih izmjena Zakona o socijalnoj i dječijoj zaštiti, predložili bismo sveobuhvatni Reformski paket koordinacije socijalne sigurnosti koji istovremeno rješava pitanja socijalne zaštite, prenosivosti penzija, invalidskog osiguranja i naknada za nezaposlene. Implementacija bi slijedila šestomjesečnu pripremnu fazu tokom koje bi Centri za socijalni rad i Fond PIO dobili ciljanu podršku za izgradnju kapaciteta. Socijalni savjet bio bi formalno konsultovan, a Procjena regulatornog uticaja bila bi završena prije glasanja u parlamentu.
key_changes_mne: Objediniti izmjene Zakona o socijalnoj i dječijoj zaštiti sa paralelnim izmjenama Zakona o penzijskom i invalidskom osiguranju i Zakona o zapošljavanju i osiguranju od nezaposlenosti, kako bi se stvorio sveobuhvatni paket usklađenosti sa Poglavljem 2.
Uvesti šestomjesečni vacatio legis uz obaveznu certifikaciju institucionalne spremnosti od strane Ministarstva, prije stupanja odredbi na snagu.
Obavezati izradu Procjene regulatornog uticaja sa petogodišnjim fiskalnim projekcijama kao preduslov za parlamentarnu raspravu.
Zahtijevati formalnu konsultaciju Socijalnog savjeta i objaviti mišljenja socijalnih partnera uz zakonodavni tekst.

Osnovati posebnu jedinicu za koordinaciju prekogranične socijalne sigurnosti unutar Ministarstva, radi rješavanja složenih slučajeva koji se odnose na mobilne radnike iz EU, čime bi se smanjio teret lokalnih Centara za socijalni rad.
Vezati produženje određenih neosiguranih naknada za postojanje recipročnih bilateralnih sporazuma u toku pretpristupnog perioda.
expected_benefits_mne: Potpuna i suštinska usklađenost sa Poglavljem 2, a ne djelimično usklađivanje koje nosi rizik negativne ocjene Evropske komisije u oblasti koordinacije sistema socijalne sigurnosti.
Operativno pripremljene institucije koje mogu pružati jednak tretman u praksi, a ne samo na papiru, sprječavajući de facto diskriminaciju putem administrativnih kašnjenja.
Fiskalno odgovorna implementacija sa transparentnim projekcijama troškova, što Ministarstvu finansija omogućava planiranje budžetskih izdvajanja.
Ojačan socijalni dijalog u skladu sa zahtjevima pristupanja EU u okviru Poglavlja 19 (Socijalna politika i zapošljavanje).
Zaštita interesa crnogorskih radnika u inostranstvu putem reciprocitetnih veza tokom pretpristupne tranzicije.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka. Zakonodavni sadržaj ostao bi suštinski isti; ključna promjena odnosi se na redoslijed, institucionalnu pripremu i sveobuhvatnost. Šestomjesečno odlaganje je umjereno i ne bi ugrozilo pregovarački vremenski okvir za Poglavlje 2, koji se odvija u višegodišnjim horizontima. Evropska komisija dosljedno je više cijenila kvalitet prenošenja propisa nego brzinu, a sveobuhvatni paket vjerovatno bi bio prihvaćen povoljnije od djelimičnih izmjena.

assessments.summary_mne: Predložene izmjene i dopune Zakona o socijalnoj i dječjoj zaštiti predstavljaju neophodan i široko prihvaćen korak ka pristupanju EU, usklađivanjem Crne Gore s Direktivom 2014/54/EU i zahtjevima Poglavlja 2 (Sloboda kretanja radnika). Proširenje jednakih prava socijalne i dječje zaštite na građane EU, EEP-a i Švajcarske istovremeno je i pravna obaveza na putu pristupanja i signal institucionalne zrelosti. Međutim, Ministarstvo ima ozbiljne zabrinutosti u pogledu izostanka analize fiskalnog uticaja, spremnosti centara za socijalni rad da upravljaju novim predmetima, nedostatka zaštitnih mehanizama uzajamnosti tokom predpristupnog perioda, kao i izostanka koordinacije s okvirima penzijskog i invalidskog osiguranja.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ovo je suštinski dobra zakonodavna inicijativa neophodna za pristupanje EU, ali se sprovodi ishitreno i suviše usko. Ključna zabrinutost Ministarstva tiče se činjenice da izmjenama i dopunama nije priložena procjena fiskalnog uticaja ni plan institucionalnih kapaciteta, a propust da se istovremeno adresiraju prenosivost penzija i koordinacija tržišta rada prijeti stvaranjem nepotpunog i operativno preopterećenog okvira. Preporučujemo faznu implementaciju praćenu mjerama izgradnje kapaciteta.
key_concerns_mne: Nije objavljena Procjena regulatornog uticaja niti fiskalna analiza kojom bi se kvantifikovali budžetski troškovi proširenja prava na novu kategoriju korisnika.
Centrima za socijalni rad nedostaju kadrovski kapaciteti, IT infrastruktura i višejezični kapacitet za obradu zahtjeva državljana EU i EEP-a bez značajnih pripremnih ulaganja.
Koordinacija penzijskog i invalidskog osiguranja u skladu s Uredbom (EZ) br. 883/2004 nije razmatrana, čime se stvara nepotpun i asimetričan okvir usklađenosti s Poglavljem 2.
Trenutno stupanje na snagu ne ostavlja prostor za period tranzicije neophodan za institucionalnu pripremu, obuku osoblja ili prilagodbu IT sistema.

Socijalni savjet i socijalni partneri očigledno nisu konsultovani, čime se krše principi socijalnog dijaloga koji su od ključnog značaja kako za pristupanje EU, tako i za konvencije MOR-a koje je Crna Gora ratifikovala.

Jednostrano proširenje potpunog jednakog tretmana prije pristupanja, bez zaštitnih mehanizama uzajamnosti ili veze s bilateralnim sporazumima o socijalnoj sigurnosti, stvara jednostranu fiskalnu obavezu.
recommendations_mne: Sprovesti i objaviti potpunu Procjenu regulatornog uticaja, uključujući fiskalne projekcije za narednih pet godina, koje pokrivaju sve kategorije davanja u okviru Zakona o socijalnoj i dječjoj zaštiti.

Uvesti vacatio legis od najmanje šest mjeseci kako bi se centrima za socijalni rad omogućila operativna priprema, uključujući obuku osoblja o upravljanju prekograničnim predmetima i nadogradnju IT sistema za provjeru prava stranih državljana.

Podnijeti paralelne izmjene i dopune Zakona o penzijskom i invalidskom osiguranju radi usklađivanja Fonda PIO s Uredbom (EZ) br. 883/2004, čime bi se osigurao sveobuhvatan pristup usklađenosti s Poglavljem 2.
Uputiti izmjene i dopune Socijalnom savjetu na formalnu konsultaciju s reprezentativnim sindikatima i udruženjima poslodavaca prije parlamentarnog usvajanja.

Razviti tranzicijski okvir koji opseg prava dostupnih državljanima EU uslovljava postojanjem bilateralnih ili multilateralnih sporazuma o socijalnoj sigurnosti koji osiguravaju uzajaman tretman crnogorskih radnika u inostranstvu.

Obezbijediti namjenska budžetska sredstva Zavodu za zapošljavanje i centrima za socijalni rad za pružanje usluga na više jezika, te za kampanju javnog informisanja namijenjenu kako mobilnim radnicima iz EU, tako i crnogorskim institucijama.

assessments.summary: This decision is a welcome and necessary step toward EU accession that indirectly strengthens the health policy framework by aligning social protection rights for mobile workers. While the amendments directly target the Law on Social and Child Protection rather than health legislation per se, the implications for healthcare access, cross-border patient mobility, and health workforce dynamics are significant. The Ministry of Health views this positively but notes that parallel amendments to health-specific legislation, particularly the Law on Health Insurance and the Law on Healthcare, are essential to ensure full compliance with the EU acquis and to prevent implementation gaps.
assessments.executive_summary: The Ministry of Health supports this alignment with EU Directive 2014/54/EU as a necessary accession step. However, equalizing social protection rights without simultaneously addressing health insurance portability and healthcare access creates a regulatory gap that could generate confusion for mobile workers and strain on the healthcare system. We recommend urgent companion amendments to health legislation and capacity planning for the Clinical Center of Montenegro and primary care networks.
assessments.reasoning:
The decision to equalize social protection rights for EU, EEA, and Swiss citizens is a structurally sound move in the context of closing Chapter 2 on Freedom of Movement of Workers. From the health perspective, several dimensions require careful analysis.

First, regarding healthcare access and health insurance: Social protection and health protection are deeply intertwined but legally distinct in Montenegro. The RFZO (Republican Health Insurance Fund) administers compulsory health insurance under the Law on Health Insurance, which currently ties entitlements primarily to Montenegrin citizenship or legal residency with employment. Extending social protection rights without explicit parallel amendments to health insurance legislation risks creating an asymmetry where EU workers have equal social benefits but unclear or incomplete health coverage. EU Directive 2014/54/EU and the broader framework of Regulation (EC) No 883/2004 on coordination of social security systems require that health insurance rights be portable and non-discriminatory. Montenegro must ensure its health insurance framework is equally aligned.

Second, regarding healthcare system capacity: Montenegro's healthcare system serves approximately 620,000 people with a network that is already under pressure, particularly at the Clinical Center of Montenegro in Podgorica and regional hospitals in Niksic, Bijelo Polje, and Bar. While the number of EU mobile workers currently in Montenegro is modest, the legal framework being established will apply post-accession when mobility could increase substantially. The coastal municipalities, which already experience seasonal population surges from tourism, could see additional demand from EU workers in hospitality, construction, and services sectors. The Ministry must plan for incremental capacity needs rather than be caught unprepared.

Third, regarding health workforce implications: This is a double-edged issue. Equalizing rights facilitates the free movement of health workers, which could exacerbate Montenegro's existing brain drain problem. Montenegrin doctors and nurses already leave for Germany, Slovenia, and other EU states offering significantly higher salaries. However, the reciprocal framework could also allow Montenegro to attract health professionals from the region, particularly if combined with targeted recruitment policies. The decision itself does not address health workforce mobility, but it sets the legal stage for it.

Fourth, on EU health standards alignment: The decision contributes to the broader accession narrative and demonstrates legislative willingness to adopt the EU acquis. Chapter 28 on Consumer and Health Protection, which remains a separate negotiation track, will require much deeper reforms in pharmaceutical regulation, food safety, communicable disease surveillance, and patient rights. This decision does not substitute for those reforms but creates a positive signal of legislative momentum.

Fifth, on pharmaceutical policy: There is no direct impact on pharmaceutical regulation from this decision. However, as Montenegro aligns its social protection framework with EU standards, questions will arise about whether EU mobile workers can access subsidized medicines from the RFZO positive list on the same terms as Montenegrin citizens. This requires clarification in secondary legislation.

The immediate-effect provision is also notable. While politically expedient for demonstrating accession progress, it leaves little time for the RFZO, the Ministry of Health, and healthcare institutions to prepare administrative procedures, IT systems for cross-border insurance verification, and staff training on the new entitlements.
key_concerns: No companion amendments to the Law on Health Insurance or the Law on Healthcare have been announced, creating a regulatory gap between social protection rights and health coverage entitlements for EU mobile workers.

The RFZO lacks established administrative procedures and IT infrastructure for verifying and processing health insurance claims from EU and EEA nationals under a portability framework akin to the European Health Insurance Card system.
Immediate effect upon publication leaves no transition period for healthcare institutions to adapt intake procedures, train staff, or update patient registration systems.
Potential incremental demand on already strained healthcare infrastructure, particularly in coastal municipalities with high concentrations of seasonal EU workers.
Risk of accelerating health workforce brain drain as the legal framework for free movement of workers becomes more robust, without offsetting retention measures for Montenegrin health professionals.
Lack of clarity on whether EU mobile workers would access RFZO-subsidized pharmaceuticals from the positive list on equal terms, which has budgetary implications.
recommendations: Urgently draft and submit companion amendments to the Law on Health Insurance and the Law on Healthcare to ensure EU mobile workers have explicit, non-discriminatory access to compulsory health insurance on the same terms as Montenegrin citizens.

Begin preparatory work with the RFZO to establish administrative and IT systems compatible with the European Health Insurance Card framework and Regulation (EC) No 883/2004, even prior to full EU membership.
Commission a capacity impact assessment for the healthcare system, focusing on municipalities with high concentrations of foreign workers, including Budva, Kotor, Tivat, and Podgorica.

Develop a health workforce retention strategy with financial incentives, career development pathways, and improved working conditions to counterbalance the increased ease of outward mobility that this legal framework enables.
Issue a ministerial instruction clarifying pharmaceutical access rights for EU mobile workers, including whether and how the RFZO positive list applies to them.

Request a reasonable transition period of at least 90 days before full implementation to allow healthcare institutions to prepare, or alternatively issue interim administrative guidelines immediately upon publication.

counter_proposal.title: Integrated Social and Health Protection Alignment Package
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than amending only the Law on Social and Child Protection in isolation, the Ministry of Health would propose a coordinated legislative package that simultaneously amends social protection, health insurance, and healthcare access legislation. This integrated approach would close regulatory gaps, demonstrate comprehensive Chapter 2 compliance, and also advance progress on Chapter 28. It would include a dedicated implementation roadmap for the RFZO and healthcare institutions, ensuring that the legal rights created on paper are operationally deliverable from day one.
key_changes: Bundle amendments to the Law on Social and Child Protection with parallel amendments to the Law on Health Insurance (Zakon o zdravstvenom osiguranju) and the Law on Healthcare (Zakon o zdravstvenoj zastiti) to create a unified non-discrimination framework for EU mobile workers.
Establish an RFZO implementation task force to develop cross-border health insurance verification procedures and begin technical alignment with EU social security coordination systems.
Include a 90-day implementation period after publication to allow healthcare facilities and the RFZO to operationalize the new entitlements.

Introduce a health workforce retention fund, financed through savings from more efficient cross-border insurance coordination, to provide salary supplements and professional development for healthcare workers in shortage specialties.
Add explicit provisions on pharmaceutical access for EU mobile workers, clarifying their entitlements under the RFZO positive list.
expected_benefits: Eliminates the regulatory gap between social protection rights and health coverage, preventing confusion and potential disputes with EU mobile workers.
Advances not only Chapter 2 but also demonstrates substantive progress on Chapter 28, strengthening Montenegro's overall accession negotiation position.
Gives the RFZO and healthcare institutions adequate preparation time, reducing the risk of implementation failures and patient safety incidents.
Proactively addresses health workforce retention, mitigating the brain drain risk that accompanies freedom of movement frameworks.
Creates a replicable model for future legislative alignment efforts, establishing the principle of integrated impact assessment across related policy domains.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible. The companion health legislation amendments are technically straightforward and draw on well-established EU templates. The RFZO task force can be established by ministerial decision without additional legislation. The main constraint is political, as it requires inter-ministerial coordination between the Ministry of Health, the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare, and the EU Integration Office, which may slow the timeline by 4 to 8 weeks. However, the quality gain substantially outweighs the modest delay.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Integrisani paket usklađivanja socijalne i zdravstvene zaštite
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto da se izmijeni samo Zakon o socijalnoj i dječijoj zaštiti u izolaciji, Ministarstvo zdravlja predložilo bi koordinisani zakonodavni paket koji istovremeno mijenja propise o socijalnoj zaštiti, zdravstvenom osiguranju i pristupu zdravstvenoj zaštiti. Ovaj integrisani pristup zatvorio bi regulatorne praznine, demonstrirao sveobuhvatnu usklađenost sa Poglavljem 2 i istovremeno unaprijedio napredak u okviru Poglavlja 28. Paket bi sadržao i poseban plan implementacije za RFZO i zdravstvene ustanove, osiguravajući da prava stvorena na papiru budu operativno ostvariva od prvog dana.
key_changes_mne: Objediniti izmjene Zakona o socijalnoj i dječijoj zaštiti s paralelnim izmjenama Zakona o zdravstvenom osiguranju i Zakona o zdravstvenoj zaštiti, kako bi se stvorio jedinstven okvir nediskriminacije za mobilne radnike iz EU.
Uspostaviti radnu grupu RFZO-a za razvoj procedura verifikacije prekograničnog zdravstvenog osiguranja i pokrenuti tehničko usklađivanje sa sistemima koordinacije socijalne sigurnosti EU.
Predvidjeti period implementacije od 90 dana nakon objave, kako bi zdravstvene ustanove i RFZO mogli operacionalizovati nova prava.

Uvesti fond za zadržavanje zdravstvenih radnika, finansiran uštedama ostvarenim kroz efikasniju koordinaciju prekograničnog osiguranja, s ciljem obezbjeđivanja dodataka na platu i stručnog usavršavanja za zdravstvene radnike u deficitarnim specijalnostima.
Dodati izričite odredbe o pristupu ljekovima za mobilne radnike iz EU, kojima se pojašnjavaju njihova prava u okviru pozitivne liste RFZO-a.
expected_benefits_mne: Eliminiše regulatornu prazninu između prava iz socijalne zaštite i zdravstvenog pokrića, sprječavajući zabunu i potencijalne sporove s mobilnim radnicima iz EU.
Unapređuje ne samo Poglavlje 2, već i demonstrira suštinski napredak u Poglavlju 28, jačajući ukupnu pregovaračku poziciju Crne Gore u procesu pristupanja.
Obezbjeđuje RFZO-u i zdravstvenim ustanovama dovoljno vremena za pripremu, smanjujući rizik od neuspjeha u implementaciji i incidenata koji ugrožavaju bezbjednost pacijenata.
Proaktivno se bavi zadržavanjem zdravstvenih radnika, ublažavajući rizik od odliva mozgova koji prati okvire slobode kretanja.
Stvara model koji se može primijeniti u budućim naporima zakonodavnog usklađivanja, uspostavljajući princip integrisane procjene uticaja u međusobno povezanim oblastima politike.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Umjereno izvodljivo. Prateće izmjene zdravstvenog zakonodavstva su tehnički jednostavne i oslanjaju se na dobro utvrđene šablone EU. Radna grupa RFZO-a može se uspostaviti ministarskom odlukom bez dodatnog zakonodavstva. Glavni ograničavajući faktor je politički — zahtijeva međuminstarsku koordinaciju između Ministarstva zdravlja, Ministarstva rada i socijalnog staranja i Kancelarije za evropske integracije, što može usporiti rokove za 4 do 8 sedmica. Međutim, dobitak u kvalitetu znatno nadmašuje to skromno kašnjenje.

assessments.summary_mne: Ova odluka predstavlja dobrodošao i neophodan korak ka pristupanju EU, koji posredno jača okvir zdravstvene politike usklađivanjem prava na socijalnu zaštitu za mobilne radnike. Iako se izmjene direktno odnose na Zakon o socijalnoj i dječijoj zaštiti, a ne na zdravstveno zakonodavstvo kao takvo, implikacije po pristup zdravstvenoj zaštiti, prekograničnu mobilnost pacijenata i dinamiku zdravstvene radne snage su značajne. Ministarstvo zdravlja ovo ocjenjuje pozitivno, ali napominje da su paralelne izmjene zdravstveno-specifičnog zakonodavstva, posebno Zakona o zdravstvenom osiguranju i Zakona o zdravstvenoj zaštiti, neophodne kako bi se osigurala potpuna usklađenost sa pravnom tekovinom EU i spriječili propusti u primjeni.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ministarstvo zdravlja podržava ovo usklađivanje s Direktivom EU 2014/54/EU kao neophodan korak u procesu pristupanja. Međutim, izjednačavanje prava na socijalnu zaštitu bez istovremenog rješavanja pitanja prenosivosti zdravstvenog osiguranja i pristupa zdravstvenoj zaštiti stvara regulatorni jaz koji može izazvati zabunu kod mobilnih radnika i dodatno opteretiti zdravstveni sistem. Preporučujemo hitne prateće izmjene zdravstvenog zakonodavstva i planiranje kapaciteta Kliničkog centra Crne Gore i mreže primarne zdravstvene zaštite.
key_concerns_mne: Nije najavljena nijedna prateća izmjena Zakona o zdravstvenom osiguranju niti Zakona o zdravstvenoj zaštiti, čime se stvara regulatorni jaz između prava na socijalnu zaštitu i prava na zdravstveno pokriće za mobilne radnike iz EU.

RFZO nema uspostavljene administrativne procedure ni IT infrastrukturu za verifikaciju i obradu zahtjeva za zdravstveno osiguranje državljana EU i EEP-a u okviru sistema prenosivosti sličnog Evropskoj kartici zdravstvenog osiguranja.
Neposredno stupanje na snagu po objavljivanju ne ostavlja prelazni period zdravstvenim ustanovama da prilagode procedure prijema, obuče osoblje ili ažuriraju sisteme registracije pacijenata.
Potencijalni porast pritiska na ionako opterećenu zdravstvenu infrastrukturu, posebno u primorskim opštinama s visokom koncentracijom sezonskih radnika iz EU.
Rizik od ubrzavanja odliva zdravstvene radne snage kako pravni okvir za slobodno kretanje radnika postaje čvršći, bez kompenzatornih mjera za zadržavanje crnogorskih zdravstvenih profesionalaca.
Nedostatak jasnoće u pogledu toga da li mobilni radnici iz EU imaju pravo na lijekove sa pozitivne liste sufinansirane od strane RFZO pod jednakim uslovima, što ima budžetske implikacije.
recommendations_mne: Hitno izraditi i podnijeti prateće izmjene Zakona o zdravstvenom osiguranju i Zakona o zdravstvenoj zaštiti kako bi se mobilnim radnicima iz EU osigurao eksplicitan i nediskriminatorni pristup obaveznom zdravstvenom osiguranju pod istim uslovima kao i crnogorskim državljanima.

Pokrenuti pripremne aktivnosti s RFZO-om radi uspostavljanja administrativnih i IT sistema kompatibilnih s okvirom Evropske kartice zdravstvenog osiguranja i Uredbom (EZ) br. 883/2004, još i prije punopravnog članstva u EU.
Naručiti procjenu uticaja na kapacitete zdravstvenog sistema, s fokusom na opštine s visokom koncentracijom stranih radnika, uključujući Budvu, Kotor, Tivat i Podgoricu.

Razviti strategiju zadržavanja zdravstvene radne snage s finansijskim podsticajima, putevima karijernog razvoja i poboljšanim uslovima rada, kako bi se uravnotežila povećana lakoća odlaska u inostranstvo koju ovaj pravni okvir omogućava.
Izdati ministarsko uputstvo kojim se pojašnjavaju prava na pristup lijekovima za mobilne radnike iz EU, uključujući pitanje da li i na koji način se na njih primjenjuje pozitivna lista RFZO-a.

Zatražiti razuman prelazni period od najmanje 90 dana prije potpune primjene kako bi zdravstvene ustanove imale vremena za pripremu, ili alternativno odmah po objavljivanju izdati privremene administrativne smjernice.

debate.consensus_summary: All ten ministries agree that equalizing social protection rights for EU, EEA, and Swiss citizens is a necessary and broadly positive step toward closing EU accession Chapter 2 and transposing Directive 2014/54/EU into Montenegrin law. There is universal recognition that this legislative amendment advances Montenegro's EU integration trajectory. Every ministry that expressed concern nonetheless endorsed the strategic direction. The points of consensus include: (1) the decision is legally and politically required for EU accession progress; (2) the immediate fiscal impact is likely small given the current low number of EU mobile workers in Montenegro; (3) administrative readiness of Centres for Social Work and related institutions is insufficient and must be urgently addressed; (4) a fiscal impact assessment should have accompanied the amendments; and (5) reciprocity for Montenegrin workers in EU member states remains an unresolved asymmetry that must be pursued in parallel.
disagreements: Urgency versus preparedness: The Ministry of EU Integration and Ministry of Economy strongly favor immediate enactment to demonstrate accession momentum, while the Ministries of Justice, Labour, Health, and Interior warn that immediate entry into force without a vacatio legis or transition period risks implementation failure, legal uncertainty, and institutional unpreparedness.

Scope of legislative reform: The Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Health, and Ministry of Labour argue that amending only the Law on Social and Child Protection is insufficient and risks legal fragmentation, insisting on parallel amendments to health insurance, pension, disability, and employment legislation. The Ministry of EU Integration and Ministry of Economy prioritize speed and view this amendment as a first critical step that can be followed by companion legislation.

Fiscal risk tolerance: The Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Labour emphasize the absence of a Regulatory Impact Assessment and fiscal projections, viewing this as a governance deficiency. The Ministry of Economy and Ministry of EU Integration acknowledge the concern but argue the immediate fiscal exposure is negligible and should not delay adoption.

Fraud and security risks: The Ministry of Interior raises concerns about organized criminal exploitation through identity fraud and fictitious employment schemes to extract social benefits, a risk not addressed by other ministries. The Ministry of EU Integration does not reference security or fraud dimensions in its assessment.

Social dialogue and consultation: The Ministry of Labour notes that the Social Council and social partners were apparently not consulted, which it views as a violation of social dialogue principles central to both EU accession and ILO conventions. Other ministries do not raise this procedural concern.

Legislative prioritization: The Ministry of Environment questions why Chapter 2 legislation receives urgent parliamentary attention while Chapter 27 environmental legislation languishes, raising concerns about imbalanced accession priorities.

Brain drain risk: The Ministries of Education and Health warn that strengthening free movement frameworks may accelerate the departure of qualified Montenegrin professionals, particularly teachers, medical staff, and STEM graduates. The Ministry of Economy frames mobility as a net positive for attracting skilled EU workers to Montenegro.
